Posted: August 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is a minimalistic optimization game where you are presented with various symbols representing metro stations with commuters represented by smaller symbols. Your job? Connect the station with coloured lines representing metro lines,  allowing metro trains represented by rectangles to transport the commuters to their desired destination. You lose when too many passengers are waiting on a station. And that's it!The art style and the soundtrack are minimalistic and very clear: the game uses bright colours and clear shapes so you can clearly see the current situation. Meanwhile, each event produces a sound: communers appearing make a *plop* sound, each train plays a section of a sound file when travelling, and a ticking noise is heard when too many passengers are waiting. I was pleasantly surprised that this didn't make a cacophony, but a pleasant almost melodious arrangement of seemingly random sounds. It is very relaxing, and now you don't only see that you made a good working metro network, but you can hear it too!The difficulty lies of course not in solving the puzzle, but in optimizing it. Everyone can make a good functioning metro system, but creating a well optimized network requires clever thinking combined with trial and error. You can compare your scores to that of the world and friends, giving you the motivation to perform better. This game is easy to learn, but hard to master.Tl;dr: Optimize a metro system, represented by minimalistic vectors and melodious sound effects. Buy it now, because a price increase is coming soon! Posted: September 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								As of today, sept. 4th, 2015, Mini Metro is still in development. But it's already a fully playable (and enjoyable) game.Mini Metro is a minimalist game, in the sense that:- the goal is simple (keep your metro network working as fluidly as possible)- the gameplay elements are simple (as time goes on, you gain more lines, train, tunnel...)- the ergonomics are simple (draw a line between two stations and you've built a new metro line ; click and drop a train on a line and it'll immediately work on its own schedule)- the look is simple (as you can see, the visuals are inspired by subway maps you can find all around the world)But a minimalist game isn't a simple game. Each station has a specific shape. Imagine that a circle represents a residential district and that a triangle represents a business area. Passengers will then tend to go from a circle to triangle. And back. But as time goes, new shapes appear. And it really feels like if a city was blooming before your eyes. Again, imagine that a square is a commercial district, a star is a tourist area,  a diamond is an airport... Some of the shapes will appear in large numbers and close together. Others will be scarce but will be a favorite destination from all around the map. Again, just like in a real blooming city.Add to that the fact that a dozen of real life cites are present in the game, each with a different feel, different tools, different obstacles.To put it simply, the game is already perfect as it is. Posted: November 11, 2015
												Mini Metro is a casual strategy game with a minimalist aesthetic. You play as a train system designer connecting stations together in the most efficient way possible, but new stations and more passangers use your system over time. The difficulty of this game ramps up so nicely, starting as a slow, casual connect-the-dot style game with relaxing music to a fast-paced strategy game where you'll be thinking about how to restructure a metro system without interrupting the current flow to minimize use of distance, interchanges, and bridges. All in the span of about 20 to 30 minutes.

Posted: January 2
												Bought this game because I loved its design and simplicity, and it turned out to be a lot more addicting that I expected. It's a game all about optimization. If you're looking for a light puzzle game you can relax to after a long day, this is perfect for you. I love how short and sweet each game is - typically around 15 minutes or so. However, if you are looking for something that will really challenge your thinking abilities until your brain hurts, this is probably not the game for you. In Mini Metro, you won't ever really have an "Aha!" moment that a lot of puzzle game provides because there is no definite end goal or solution. You just keep on optimizing until the city's population overwhelms your metro system.

Posted: September 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								As of today, sept. 4th, 2015, Mini Metro is still in development. But it's already a fully playable (and enjoyable) game.Mini Metro is a minimalist game, in the sense that:- the goal is simple (keep your metro network working as fluidly as possible)- the gameplay elements are simple (as time goes on, you gain more lines, train, tunnel...)- the ergonomics are simple (draw a line between two stations and you've built a new metro line ; click and drop a train on a line and it'll immediately work on its own schedule)- the look is simple (as you can see, the visuals are inspired by subway maps you can find all around the world)But a minimalist game isn't a simple game. Each station has a specific shape. Imagine that a circle represents a residential district and that a triangle represents a business area. Passengers will then tend to go from a circle to triangle. And back. But as time goes, new shapes appear. And it really feels like if a city was blooming before your eyes. Again, imagine that a square is a commercial district, a star is a tourist area,  a diamond is an airport... Some of the shapes will appear in large numbers and close together. Others will be scarce but will be a favorite destination from all around the map. Again, just like in a real blooming city.Add to that the fact that a dozen of real life cites are present in the game, each with a different feel, different tools, different obstacles.To put it simply, the game is already perfect as it is. But it's still quite hard to explain and you really have to experience how it works, for it's both a very stressing and demanding game and a most contemplative and artistic pice of work.

Posted: April 16
												I have always been fascinated with simulations of real life things. As a kid, I dug SimTower trying to build the greatest skyscraper everrrrr (unfortunately, it took a lot of micromanaging so I got bored after I hit 4 stars). With Mini Metro, I lay my hands on a very simplistic type of simulation: You have to connect different spots on the map (which is based on real life cities) in order to build a functioning public transportation system. Starting out slowly, you soon hit the point where your passengers get annoyed and complain because they have to wait too long (it's not like nobody has ever been in that state of mind). It takes careful planning and managing your lines to be successful until the inevitable overcrowded station. Different cities also have different assets to their system such as high-speed trains or interchanges that don't overcrowd as fast. It is a lot of fun on the way there and adds some variation by the Daily Challenge as well as a sandbox-like endless mode. I enjoy playing it whenever I am sick of the fast-paced multiplayer games I usually play.

Posted: October 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you like the bold lines and abstract shapes of the Harry Beck-style transit map, then this is your chance to dive into one up to your armpits. It is simple to get to grips with but incredibly complex to learn, because you're dealing with an NP complete problem that keeps evolving as you play. It's laid back and relaxed but frenetic at the same time, because who knows when you'll have to redraw your entire network all of a sudden and it will test you to the limit. This game is already one of my top five all-time favourites, because until I played it I had no idea just how long I'd been waiting for it.At it's core Mini Metro is a strategy game, but not in the sense of combat, but in one of motion, logistics. Balancing the economics of time, distance and people in simple lines and abstract geometric shapes. It's easy to get into but so difficult to master, combined with the random nature of the gameplay, that gives it an incredible amount of longevity.Buy it. Buy it for a friend. Buy it for a family member. Buy it for a co-worker. Play it. Enjoy it. Love it. It's well worth the asking price.

Posted: May 27, 2016
												I'll thumbs this one up for being both original and simple. This game is a schoolbook example of elegance in abstract design: here's a map, shaped points (stations) are going to crop up and will slowly get filled up by small shapes (passengers) that need to get to one of the other shapes, and here are a couple routes you can draw as you want. Keep the stations from becoming overcrowded as long as possible.As you can guess, going about this is growing slowly more complex with every added station. To which route will you add this? Will you make a detour or redesign things? How will the extra travel time affect the waiting times? And will the resulting choice make sure that the route passes through enough different shapes to make sure everyone actually gets on the train?Sorry...I'm getting off-topic, but for good reason: the graphics are as simple as can be, the music is relaxing but has or needs (pretty much?) no sounds and controls are just left-mouse buttons. What's there to talk about? (okay, the controls sometimes need some getting used to, but still...). Perhaps that I sort of expected this to be a (very good quality) mobile game as well, but mobile users won't be able (yet) to play this game about building a commute system. :PAt this point, I feel like I've both gotten a good idea what the game is about and not having an idea how to PROPERLY play the game at all. And that's a compliment to the depth I'm sure it has to offer... :-)

Posted: June 28, 2016
												TL;DR 10/10 addictive and very challengingThis game is absolutely amazing. At first it looked like a very easy game with extremely easy control, but soon it turns into some extreme mind-boggling puzzle requiring real time strategy.- GameplayAs time goes on, new stops are built and you need to connect them in such a way that passengers can move conveniently without overcrowding on the stops. Per week you get new resources, such as the ability to construct a new line, getting additional locomotives or wagons, tunnels, bridges etc., being a finite resource. The only infinit thing is the way and length of the tracks. The amount of passengers increases and stops keep appearing at random locations and you need to find the most efficient way to get them from A to B. The passengers and stops are somewhat marked to where they desire to go and what the stops look like, but it's very abstract and it's there to give you just a basic idea.- The game itselfThe game is designed according to a very abstract concept. It looks as clean as it could be and is really all you need. The sounds are also somewhat pleasing, you can turn it off if you wish though.- ConclusionIt's a fun and challenging game to play after a hard day of work and what seems like a relaxing game, turns into a very complex puzzle and requires you to pay attention all the time and sometimes even to pauze and fundamentally redesign your network. Yet, it stays fun and you are free to do what you want.

content:
Posted: March 3
												Mini Metro is a pleasant ambient experience of spinning plates. Plates that are trains, and the poles are also trains. So are your hands, they're also trains.Pleasant plinks and plonks are what transpire as you connect sporadically spawning train stations to your colourful lines and it's all very calming. It's a simple affair of sending triangles to their triangular getaways and the squares to their loser square stations and you can just begin to feel your heartrate slow and your muscles relax and you've finally found a way to calm down after a long day's of work that doesn't invovle rampant alcoholism.Suddenly stations keep spawning. Your stations keep getting busier. You're plagued by circular stations, filling your trains with♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥wanting to go anywhere BUT the 5 circular stations that await them along the next stretch of your blue line. Stations are filling rapidly. Your trains can't cope! Panic sets in! Maybe if you move a carriage to a train on a different line?OH NO! It was too late, the full train has already passed the rapidly over crowding station, making this extra carriage nothing more than a large metallic bauble. Your perfect distribution of stations along your other lines is suddenly thrown into chaos as one of them transforms from a lynchpin of a triangle into a nightmare of a leaf shape! LEAVES ARE LITERALLY ON THE TRACK AND CAUSING ISSUES!You're promptly sacked from your job as a metro manager.It's a great game.Lots of locations that all had their own unique quirks and tube map layouts. Short fun games that'll help you unwind and lose yourself to the madness of rail layouts.(More HERE[mozillogames.tumblr.com])

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												I have not a single bad thing to say about this game. I bought this game around April this year when it was early access after I saw a youtuber play it just out of the blue. As I was watching the video I thought that this could be a game that I would enjoy. After purchasing it I played it for a little while and could see myself getting addicted to it. The concept of the game is simple; run a subway/metro at one of the many locations from around the world that the developers have offered. To do this it is as simple as clicking and dragging the lines to the new stations that continue to appear as your progress through the weeks. At the end of the week you receive a new locomotive and you also then get the choice between two options that are given to you. They could be a new line, a new carriage, tunnels (which come in handy on the maps that have bodies of water that must be traversed) or even an interchange (these come in handy when you have one particular stop with many lines running through it.)The actual design of the game is simplistic and minimalistic in nature. Since April the design of the interface itself has changed and developed into one of the nicest looking interfaces I have seen. It is easy on the eyes and is easy to navigate so any new comers could easily immerse themselves in the game.The developers themselves have been continually updating this game for the players, adding new challenges and content to keep it interesting. Never fear however, even if these challenges were not available you would still find yourself lost in the game. Each play through on any map is extremely different to any previous play throughs due to the fact that each station that spawns in is random. Thus this keeps the game from becoming stale and keeps it rather interesting as you can never guess where and what kind of station will show up next.Keeping up with everything can be a real challenge at times, especially as more and more stops appear on the map and more and more passengers wait at these stops. Even so that does not make the game at all stressful and is actually oddly peaceful and satisfying to play.Every time I play I find myself saying, "Just one more week (in game) and I'll stop" but that one more week turns into two more weeks which turns into three more weeks and before I know it I have spent 3 hours in the game. The simple drive to keep the lines running as smoothly as possible and to get as many passengers to their destination as possible is the thing that becomes rather addictive.  Overall it is fantastic. The design is utterly perfect for this kind of game (it looks just like a metro map would), the controls are extremely easy, there are plenty of cities to play, the interface is minimalistic and overall the dev team have done a wonderful job. I would suggest anyone buy it really. Even if you only play it on the off occasion for an hour or two it is totally worth it!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27
												Mini Metro is a calming, charming minimalist puzzle game - lots of buzzwords there I know, but it's very pleasant in its simplicity. You draw lines between stations, which are denoted with shapes (triangles, squares, etc) and passengers want to go to specifically shaped stations. Gameplay therefore is optimizing your lines so square passengers aren't waiting forever to get to the square station, and so on.Complexity is added with special stations, an increasing spawn rate of passengers and new stations (thus increasing the pressure on you) and upgrades that you get every week, from new lines, new carriages, to other, special things. There's a good variety in maps, too - not only do they have new layouts for the stations, they throw in rivers and lakes that you need to navigate around or over with your limited stock of tunnels and bridges.It hits that sweet spot between simplicity and complexity, basically. So - extras. There's the main mode, there's an endless mode, there's Extreme mode where you can't redraw any of your lines (yikes!) and there are the daily challenges, which hand you a random map and mode and compare your score with the internet's. There's a speed setting, so you can pause the game or speed it up as needed, although it doesn't go as fast as I'd like in some of the slower levels...but then you hit places like Auckland and you play that map at the main speed because going slightly faster will drown you!Now: Most of Mini Metro is chill, as you sort out your trains and enjoy the maps. It's a game you can meditate to as you finish levels and collect achievements.Then you hit the second half of the achievements, where they give you crazy challenges like "you can only use two tunnels" or "every line must connect to one station". These are hard, and require total mastery of the game's mechanics as well as a little luck - but they're also a good learning curve! You realize you have to play more carefully with the first one, then slowly ramp up until you're ready to face San Francisco and Auckland. The game goes from being chill to this crazy rush where your lines must be optimized perfectly as you rush around triaging passagers with your extra lines and hoping it's enough to last until you have a high enough score.In short: Mini Metro is a lot of fun, and the challenge is nicely optional. Check it out!

content:
Posted: February 16
												I respect the hard work from the developers and appreciate the frequent updates, however some of the major design flaws make the gameplay more of a frustration than a mental challenge.A few glaring flaws:1. RNG decides how well you do. There are situations where it's absolutely impossible for you to get the city specific achievements. You can be using exactly the same strategy, and do exceptionally well/poor in different ocassions. That's unacceptable for a game that's essentially a time waster (even at maxmum speed, each game can take a long time to complete, with the first 10 mins completely boring and unnecessary).2. The game challenges you by making the same stations appearing in close proximity - many times had  I had over 6 circles (and zero of any other kind) on the same island. At this point, it becomes a chore to manage the situation, and you wonder why the developers didn't try something more refreshing to make the game challenging.3. The train loading optimization is poor - the simple rules the developer put together simply aren't enough. Here is an important one: a train should drop off passengers to pick up high priority passengers (those who are going to unique stations and the only way for them to arrive is through taking this one line).  4. The maxim speed in the game is way too slow, there should be way more then 2 levels of speed, I personally think the highest speed should be at least 3 to 4 times faster than the current maximum speed. This is very simple to implement, and making the game much less of a time waster. (At least giving the player control of how they would like to play the game.)If the developers are able to make changes to address the design flaws, I would gladly change my reccomendation to positive. After all the execution of the game is quite well and the idea has a lot of potential to be a truly fun strategy/puzzle game.

content:
Posted: February 7
												Quite ok but not perfect.A small strategy game, starting with a blank map, where different kinds of upcoming stations (that produce waiting passengers) must be connected via lines. Trains added to lines have to transport the passengers before the waiting time gets too high. Unfortunately passengers do act less logically sometimes. When a train enters a station that connects the current station to one the passengers want to go to, they still do not enter, if in the other direction the same kind of station does exist more closely as well. In reality this would make perfect sense, in Mini Metro however not really, for the passengers just should want to find any way to such a station. In my case this meant game over just before finishing the city's goal because noone entered the train. A Pain in the♥♥♥♥♥for sure. Another thing is that in San Fran from one second to another the numbers of passengers in all stations really explode so that the game is lost currently. Some updates are yet to be made to fix such issues. For some entertainment meantimes and 10€ it's a quite and nice idea however and kind of fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								I haven't been lured to write any game review till date, but I couldn't resist the urge to express how I feel about this game in specific. Although from a scale point of view, Mini Metro is probably one of the smallest games I have ever played, but this game will give you an amount of "addiction time" mega scale games can't compete with!Mini Metro get's you hooked on little things with very deep and addicting strategy addiction. Being able to play a strategy game with little things such is very rewarding. Things like a) How should I divide my routes b) Which stations should I create connections c) Should I increase carriage or lines d) which stations should connect to which linesI am a fan of large scale strategy games from Sim Cities to Tycoons to Business Sims, but this simple, minimalist yet very enjoyable game gives you instant joy without needing to wait ages for results of your strategic decisions. This is extremely valuable if you are a busy person and don't have time to play games that need hours for things to shape up!If you like strategy games and would like to get a chance of playing strategy games in casual mode, I don't thing anything can currently beat Mini Metro. Absolutely wonderful!

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29
												Disappointing this could have been an awsome game. At first, I was totally swallowed up by this game but there is a problem. There is a low ceiling to this game. Just as it gets interesting the stations overload that ends the game. And at first, you think it is because of your strategy. But that isn't the case the problem is their algorithm. Each type of station has a shape and that shape generates all but its own shape. That's not the problem. The problem is that some games only have one square station. I played Osaka this has one square there are twenty-five circles and eleven triangles they are all producing squares at the same rate as triangles and circles. At about 2500 point you will fail you can't get the square passengers all to the one square without overloading a station. And if you overload a station you loose. Now you might get a little higher in a different scenario but that's only because you have more squares.

Then, it becomes relaxing to play it, although I don't think it has many hours to offer until you get tired of it.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												This is a wonderful, relaxing little puzzle game with an attractive, minimalist style to both its audio and visuals, and mechanics straightforward enough that the game never needs to explicitly spell them out for you. Despite the simplicity of the mechanics, though, this is a brainbender extraordinaire; those of you who enjoy setting up systems to work in the most efficient manner possible will have an absolute blast here.The concept is simple: you're in control of the subway system. Stations open across the map gradually, and you need to connect them with different coloured lines. Stations have different shapes, and the shapes of the "commuters" that appear at each station represent where they want to go. You will, then, need to plan out your routes so that there's minimal inefficiency; "circle" commuters will only ever want to go to "square" or "triangle" initially, for example, so there's little sense in making a line entirely out of circle stations.As the game progresses, the map expands and the number of possible shapes for the stations increases, too, until eventually you're having to consider things like interchanges extremely carefully as well as just the routes for your lines, particularly if you're playing on the "Extreme" mode, where once you've laid a line down, you can't change it!This is a highly enjoyable, inventive puzzle game, then, and particularly recommended to those who want something a little "gentler" than the big-budget fare of today!

Early Access Review
								I have been having a good time with this game, it is currently early in development and does not have any music yet. Great to play while listening to something. Each time you play you will get better at designing sound efficient systems. The leaderboards give incentive to improve yourself. I have only played this game as of this review for 5 hours and i can see myself playing it for a lot more.It is very calm, and includes a night mode if you are not a fan of looking at a white screen the whole time. I can proudly say that for a few of the maps I am in the top 1000 best players, and I plan to do even better. Small decisions such as a new tunnel or line while small at firsst can mean a big difference. I saw this game after watching a youtube video of it by the youtuber Sips and decided to jump on it due to its simple puzzle and strategy elements. You are able to pause it at any moment to restructure your stations and routes. I give this game a solid pat on the back so to speak. I am looking forward to the new maps.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												A masterpiece of design. Clean, simple, elegant, easy to learn, and yet hard to master (try getting into the top 10% on every level). Not more than it has to be nor less, it is as close to perfect in the execution of this design concept as can probably be achieved. The only criticism I can level against the game is the randomness of the choices between days. Sometimes you just don't get any 'tunnel luck.' Also, the music and sound are pleasant at first, but as the game runs long it can layer into an annoying dishormony of sounds. Overall I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												This game is as casual as it gets.Mini Metro is a strategy-puzzle game where you must connect stations, which pop in at random intervals and are of a certain shape (circle, square, star etc), with lines and move commuters to their destinations. The commuters also possess shapes corresponding to the shape of the station they want to get to. There can be multiple stations of a certain shape (2 squares or 5 triangles and so on) so a triangle commuter may get down at any triangle station but as more and more stations pop in and your network grows and the number of commuters increase, it becomes a frantic game of figuring out which lines to connect to the new stations and where to provide new cars and trains which is where the strategy kicks in because almost everything is limited. This includes the number of lines you can place, the number of bridges (It must also be mentioned that all maps have rivers which can only be crossed by using bridges), the number of trains you are provided and the number of carriages you are given which can be used to increase a train's capacity. You are also limited by the fact that 2 lines cannot cross each other except if they meet at a station. The one respite you get is that lines can be infinitely long but even then you must be careful because a train cannot change directions midway and must move the entire length of a line before it turns back making overly long lines almost completely useless.If all this sounds frantic, it's because it is. But the beauty of this game lies in the fact that you can control the pacing of the game. Want a zen, calming experience of simply drawing lines between stations and watch commuters move almost akin to a screensaver? Or do you want to be challenged and find your way to the top of the billboards and high scores and make your mark? ell, they have that covered too. But the surprising amount of strategy required to play this game ensures that it really never gets dull even after many hours of play, partly due to the random nature of the placement of the stations hat pop up over time. There is no optimal line placement and train assignment because every play is unique. Despite being random though, the game never becomes unfair or too punishing. This might either be due to the very nature of the game and how it deals with the randomness but I never once found myself feeling that a station was unfairly placed where it was impossible to reach or unserviceable. All the various systems come together very cohesively to make for a light, casual experience or a fast-paced and urgent, but never unfair, game.The graphics are exceedingly simple, borrowing heavily from the route maps one sees on real life metros. The art style lends itself incredibly well to the gameplay, making it very easy to understand the flow of commuters at a glance simply by following the colors of the lines you placed.The audio is equally minimalistic with small sounds to indicate the flow of commuters and trains but it never crosses the line into being realistic and loud. It is simply indicative of activity and adds a lot to the already Zen nature of the game. I literally dozed off for a minute or so once playing this game and that is absolutely not a bad thing, especially after a long and tiring day of work.If you want nothing more than to sit back, relax and enjoy some calming gameplay, or if you want something with strategy and quick-thinking involved, then Mini Metro has you covered on both fronts. I highly recommend you pick this game up.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Minimalism: It is a minimalist game, above all it is minimalist by design. You can read this post[devlog.dinopoloclub.com] by the developers of this game blog.The game is really, really minimalistic, do not misunderstand me, I like also minimalistic games, but the first Steam tag is "Strategy", then "Simulation" tag. Here you will find no strategy and no simulation, just minimalism.About the gameplay, you have very few things to control, stations pop out in the game randomly, and above all even if disconnected from trails the people start to wait and going upset if they are unable to reach their kind of destination. You have no money budget to spend in something you think you need when you need it, there is no construction costs, but instead, every week you could get a new train or a new trail or a new vagon or an interchange improvement for a station, or finally a new tunnel/bridge. Naturally you can only get your week things budget if and only if your week score is high enough...There is no construction or demolition time. Stations have no range, just people that need to reach their kind of destination. If you change stations with nodes and people with weight you could play with a subset of the math graph theory...LOL...At the moment there is no editor.So, finally if and only if, you are looking for a really minimalistic game, you could be satisfied, apart the price that is not such a minimalistic price, maybe best to wait for sales, otherwise this game is really too much minimalistic...Sorry but, I have to not suggest this game to the public.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												EH.I played it a bit, and I can definitely see the appeal, but this game isn't for me.  Each level starts off easy, but quickly spirals out of control. The game tosses in new points and people for your network to accomodate, and though the growth rate of the network accelerates, your rate of aquiring assets does not. What's worse, is that I kept feeling like I just wanted it to pause for a minute so I could figure out if I was doing things right, but it grinds reletlessley forward withough giving you time to think.  I guess what I miss the most is a chance to learn and improve, but each round gets so out of hand that I don't have time to learn what I'm doing wrong. I suppose enough trial and error would get me there, but I like a game that gives me a ramp to climb instead of expecting me to fail my way through.If you dig quick games, and you enjoy hectic game play, then this may be the game for you. It's easy to learn and hard to master, and the interface is nice on the eyes. The audio ties into the actions occuring on screen, which got old quick for me, but others seem to really dig it. There's multiple game modes, and many levels.All in all, I suspect that this is a great game that I happen to have no taste for. Though others seem to love it, I don't think I'll be reccomending it to any of my friends.

Early Access Review
								For a minimalist train-simulator, this game takes up an embarrassing amount of my time. The first time I played it, I thought "well, that was fun." And then I found myself continuously coming back to it. For early access, they update it a lot. It feels finished, and nothing really early-access about it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												This is a truly unique game that should be in every puzzle lover's collection.It seems simple enough, make sure your passengers get to the stations they want to get to (your passengers being a wide array of shapes, denoting which station they want to travel to) and keep your subway system running as smoothly as possible until too many passengers overcrowd one station.It's the next Tetris. A deceptively simple brain teaser that progressively gets tougher and more unwieldy. I friggin LOVE it!You can spend hours just veging to this, and the sounds and music are relaxing and go very nicely with the game, it's an experience you should treat yourself to.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												A puzzle game about building a highly abstracted mass transit system - there is no “solution” to the puzzles, just the question of how long you can keep meeting an ever rising demand.I admire both the aesthetic and pacing of this game.The interface is beautifully minimal, both providing everything you need to understand and play the game while evoking the classic topological underground map.The pacing is well executed with periods of calm where you feel in control, followed by periods of frantic activity as new stations and special stations force rapid change across your network.So why haven’t I played it more?Access to the depth - I don’t think the game lacks meaningful choices; when I look at the scores people have achieved (more than doubling my best on my most played cities) there are clearly things I can do to improve.  However the game progression doesn’t challenge me to discover new strategies or provide the signposts to improvement in the same way that my favourite puzzle games do.Well worth a look but don't be too shocked if the initial rush expires after 8-10 hours

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								A strangely compelling puzzle game. The mechanics are simple and intuitive (they could use a more in depth tutorial for track editing, loops, and so forth, however), and it's one of the few puzzle games that felt like creative thinking was necessary. Even at Early access, it's a well made game. The solid aesthetic is refreshing, I only ran into a bug once, and it feels polished. Not finished, mind. There's still a few levels and modes missing, as well as sound (hopefully that will change for the better)

Early Access Review
								The game is basically about moving passengers from one station to the next, by using public transportation. You decide where these lines go, how they are connected and how many vehicles and carriages there are on each line. Every game starts you off softly, and get increasingly difficult as time passes. At the end of each week in the game, you recieve bonuses. Pick wisely ;)I bought this at a sale and have never regretted it. Knowing what i know now, i wouldn't mind paying full price for it either. It's a gem of a small time waster. One which i wholeheartedly reccomend to everyone who think they might be interested in this game.10/10 Excellent game for what it tries to be.

Posted: December 7, 2015
												Fiendishly additive, but at this early stage ultimately unfulfilling. I find it just gets a little too difficult, a little too quickly. It's hard to get a feel for what's working and what is not. It's very interesting through, I think I just need a little more advice and information. For instance, what are the advantagtes and disadvatages of a circular line? How many people leave and visit each station? How about some interesting stats about the various metros around the world. All in all, I like the game a lot, hence why I just want a little more.......

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is an interesting little game which is still in development at time of writing but is definitely worth a play!  The aim of the game is to create an efficient network of subway stations, so as not to allow a build up of waiting passengers at any one place.  The difficulty of the game increases the longer that it is played, allowing it to maintain a level of difficulty even when you think that you have figured out the best way to plan your network, this keeps the game playable for longer. Each time you start a game the initial nodes are randomised so no two games are identical.  There are three different modes to play the game in thus far:Normal - Don't let the stations overcrowdEndless - Aim for the most efficient networkExtreme - Lines cannot be changed once placedIf you want a game to fill a fifteen minute gap this could be for you.If you want a stratagy game which will keep you playing for a little longer, this could also be for you.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Yeah this is a pretty solid puzzler that is in Early Access. Even though there is no music, and limited features, I certainly will get my money's worth here (6.99$). Really solid gameplay mechanic that is easy to learn and probably near-impossible to master. Great minimalistic design aesthetic with addicting gameplay. The developer's also seem in-tune with the community, and really, what they claim they will add does not seem that far from what they already have in place. If there was a transport sim rogue-like, this may be it. It has:-Random depot spawns-I believe (Random) spot along the river where the focus starts-RPG-like leveling up via weekly upgrade choices and resource management-Permadeath-The ability to pauses and make decisions is not *quite* turn-based, but damned close-Ability to solve goals using different strategies (high complexity)-Player vs. worldThere is not:-Fantasy elements-Grid-based

												One of those games you can just zone out to, while still being challenging if you want to build a perfect system. It's easy to unlock all cities, but to master the game is hard. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Minimalist graphics.Train logistics.Slow building where each scenario starts with 3 stations, then adds new stations and passengers over time.By far, what I find most satisfying about this game, is watching the train simulation, watching passengers get on and off trains.  The mechanism is the same as other train simulators and the lightweight graphics don't detract from the experience and immersion.The logistics consist of creating paths so common passenger destinations are accessible in minimal stops, while rare destinations are still handled in a timely fashion.  Also, just because a station is full and a train arrives, doesn't mean anybody will get on board, since the passengers seem to choose a train going to the nearest destination, not the earliest destination... (i.e. they'll wait a week to get on the train which has their stop next, rather than getting on this train that has their stop 2 stops down in the other direction) - at least it looked like that's what they are doing.Choose between new engine types, new routes, bridges, or carriages.  As stations become overcrowded with unserviced passengers, eventually the scenario will end, with an option to continue in endless mode.  Endless mode is fun as the game turns into mostly a free-form sandbox train station simulator.  Setting up one train to have a long chain of cars is pretty nice.I loved Sid Meier's Railroad and Mini Metro provides a lot of the same enjoyment.  Gameplay starts a little too slow, and after about 2 minutes picks up enough to become interesting.  Good tension.  Each map seems to generate stops randomly, so the same map played twice can be very different.  It would be nice to have an RNG seed interface to play the same map and station order repeatedly, but the game is still enjoyable as it is.  $10 - fair price.

												One of the most elegant, perfectly conceived transportation managers I've ever seen.  Brilliantly combines transportation management with challenging strategy, engrossing patterns and minimalist game design.Playing on "Night Mode" in a dim room is a fabulously relaxing, sometimes meditative experience, especially now that such lovely audio is now built into the game.  If you have a soft spot for logistical management, interesting game design and absorbing, procedurally generated music, Mini Metro is for you!

content:
Posted: October 26, 2016
												A more fair pricing would be $5, like in iOS. :)[Edit 10/27]The game is skewed against you.While playing the game, most will reach a threshold impossible to maneuver out of, especially because of the seemingly random nature of the game. This is so because the weekly completion reward of one train does not increase exponentially with the increased amount of stations/passengers, especially increase in 'varied' stations. Then as one reaches around ~2000 passengers, the congestion becomes impossible to maneuver out of, not matter how good you play. Of course, there are some that can reach 3000 or even 4000, but this is simply due to the luck of the straw, or luck of what stations spawn where.This is a major oversight by the developers, one which shouldn't have existed to begin with. What is the point of playing something in which you know full well you will reach a certain threshold from the very beginning? Why is the weekly reward of one train when having 10 stations the same as having 30, 40 or more varied stations? Doesn't make sense.Possible fix? Increase the amount of weekly trains rewarded exponentially after a couple of weeks of play.I have asked for a refund after playing three games because there is no getting better and one can only count on better luck, not to mention it gets very repetitive. Replay value is also severely diminished knowing your imminent fate at a certain point in the game is certain.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15
												A minimalist game where you start off with a map with three stations: one circle, one square and one triangle. At each station you have people wanting to go to one of the other stations: some wanting to go to the circle, some to the square, and some to the triangle. You connect the stations by drawing a line between them and a train starts running back and forth along it. Problem solved... until another station randomly pops up on the map and you have to connect that as well.As the game goes along more stations pop up and the number of different shapes of stations increase. To combat this you are given more train lines; more trains; more carriages and so on. You have to decide how best to connect all the randomly placed stations with the resources you are given, but eventually you'll get overwhelmed trying to get the right passengers to the right type of station and one of the stations gets too many passengers waiting at it and it's game over. It's all a question of how long you can last and how many passengers you can deliver.It might be a nice little time waster for some people, but I think that the random placement of stations pretty much cancels out most differences between the different maps you're given to play on, and I don't see much fun in trying to connect a bunch of circle stations, that have all randomly appeared adjacent to each other, to the network when nobody at a circle station wants to go to another circle station.

												UhNot too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes insteadIngredients:1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour3 tablespoons sugar1 tablespoon baking powder1/4 teaspoon salt1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg2 large eggs, at room temperature1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as neededNow to make it1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

												Imagine buying diablo and there are only 5 levels of dungeon - As others have said, this game does have a good enjoyable core - but once you break free of that, which is not hard, it gets pretty dull. After 100 or so passengers a day in endless, you stop gaining things. It just keeps going, but you can't aquire any more cars or tracks. And while the design looks clean and simple; there are some very frustrating interactions. want to lay down the red track? first, select the red track then click on a station - oh wait, its laying down a blue track. There are a lot of good things done well in this game - things I really think are worth celebrating - Attentions to details that I find really exciting, and a core concept that is beautiful and elegant. I guess if anything, I would describe this game as such: a finished unfinished game with no updates in months. It's only fault is that there is not enough of it.

Early Access Review
								Strategic tube/subway system simulator, with a minimalist art style.Develop the Metro system of 10 real world cities, starting from 3 stations and steadily increasing by random, for up until one overflows. Each week you are given a choice of upgrades to choose from, and the upgrade you choose can make or break your tube system. Across 3 different game modes, and the newly implemented Daily Challenges, Mini Metro is an excellent casual game to spend half an hour on each day.

Early Access Review
								I really like the concept but unfortunately that’s all it feels like right now: a concept – not even a working beta. I can’t recommend this because it really feels like nothing more than a web-browser game. It is still open beta and it is only like $6 but still I wouldn’t pay $6 for a flash game.Aside from things clearly still in development like sound, more levels, a bunch of options and stuff like that, there’s just no meat to the game. Essentially all you’re doing is dragging lines between dots on the screen not unlike the zillion air traffic controller clones for mobiles. While I’m looking for casual as opposed to a transport simulator, it still needs more to feel like a game. How about currency, pricing, upgradables, a map that zooms out and enlarges as the game progresses, etc.?Don’t get me wrong, the game is fun and super addicting for like 5 or less hours. After that however, there’s just nothing else to do. If you can accept this and have a couple of dollars to burn, go for it. If you are neurotic and have to do simple repetitive tasks to maximize efficiency, play away. If you are looking some actual content or something more than your average free mobile game, I wouldn’t bother.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I love casual games, but I have to say this game is really boring. I know I haven't put much time in it, but that is because I got bored really quickly.This game feels like a more boring version of "Pipe Dreams", which for the younger crowd is a game where you have to build a piping system before liquid would flow and points were rewarded for the length of pipe the water traveled through before flooding out of the pipes.I digress. This game is about setting up a "metro" system to pick up shapes and deliver them to a station of the same shape. While you are setting up your "tracks" new shapes randomly appear as well as patrons. Those shapes have to be integrated into your system before the patrons get frustrated and leave at which point you lose.The bigger problem I have with this game is that there is no way of planning your system as the shape locations appear at random. There is a way to restructure your system but the interface feels unintuitive and I'm never sure if when I remove tracks/trams that they return to my inventory. From what I can tell - trams do not - and therefore you are punished for a restructure that you couldn't have planned before.This game feels like a mobile game, best experienced on the crapper.I hesitate to say this game is horrible as it has many great reviews, but as a fan of casual games - you can skip this one. Sorry devs.I will give this game more time and if my opinion changes I will update this review.

number of helpful: 4 of 23 people (17%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Minimalist, conceptually fun transport strategy game, but very buggy and badly designed. Can't accomplish anything with strategy when you spend literally all your time fighting the horrible route interface and the arbitrary, random, nonsensical design decisions that make the game more of a time waster where success is based as much on luck as on skill. I read several strategy guides and managed to make headway in the game, eventually beating all the basic level goals, but it was never enjoyable in any way because the game is so fundamentally broken and badly designed. I prefer strategy games, not luck based time wasters. The game has no sound and I literally had more fun listening to my Solar Fields ambient trance albums in the background than I did playing the game.Some examples:Metro lines frequently refuse all attempts to revise their route for absolutely no reason unless you chop out the ENTIRE line and remake it. This is a huge headache and by itself makes the game unplayable when the randomness requires adaptation. I know you can click the route near a station and then drag over the station to remove that section of the route -- I'm saying that sometimes it simply doesn't work, and for no reason that I can discern. EDIT 6/19/2015 - This was fixed in the last patchNew stations spawn randomly (you cannot build stations) and often in places that make level goals inaccessible (e.g. "Carry 1000 passengers using only 1 tunnel" but then new stations keep spawning between 2 rivers and long before the map opens up to give you more route options). Or how about the Hong Kong level goal: Move 1100 passengers with only 8 stations per line. Sounds reasonable, until you recognize that stations often spawn INTO your routes and instantly ruin your entire game on the spot. Or Berlin where you must carry the same huge number of passengers using only 1 locomotive per line. What's that? You say the end of week choices didn't offer you another line to run your end of week locomotive on? Too bad. Hit restart, try again, maybe next time you'll get luckier.Passengers often accumulate at a station with multiple empty trains passing by regularly without picking them up for absolutely no reason (connecting lines properly placed to destination, sometimes destination was even on the same line!) and this is yet more hair pulling insanity because within 30 seconds or so of passengers not being picked up at a station it's BLAM GAME OVER because the game ends the instant people have to wait too long for a train pickup. Why? I have no idea. That's just what the developer chose. Several times I got Game Over despite clearing the passengers out of the station just before the timer ran out. I don't know why. There seems to be no fundamental locational supply and demand for stations (it's all random) and only a tenuous connection between time of day and passenger movements, if there IS any connection. I get that the different geometry icons and the way they evolve independent of the player is designed to simulate a city economy moving and the metro having to adapt to changing demand but in practise the implementation is so scattered, crazy, and random that it makes no sense and is the antithesis of fun to have to deal with. Real world metrorail transport doesn't work this way. Combine this with all the other interface headaches and you'll likely be passionately hating the game before you get too far.These fundamental problems make the game generally unplayable, unenjoyable, and outright annoying, and I could not possibly recommend this pile of disasterous development and unsound design. The fact that the game has no sound has no bearing on the final verdict. It's just bad.---------------UPDATE 6/19/2015I've played this game several more hours and beat all the maps since I wrote this review and I still feel essentially the same. A patch removed the problem with track route not changing but the more I play the more I realize that the main game mode (not endless or extreme) is based almost entirely on luck of the draw with you predestined to fail sooner or later. To get the goals and unlock the extreme modes you have to have some combination of lucky starting position, lucky station spawns, and lucky end week choices. Sure, you need good planning and careful manipulation of the routes on top of that as well, but do you really want to play a game that force fails you based on luck no matter how skilled you are? I don't. I still don't recommend this game unless you like wasting time. It's a decent time waster, but a bad strategy game.

								I bought this game thinking it would be a nice way to spend my Sunday afternoon/evening with a bit of a brain puzzle, based on all of the good reviews here.The game only kept me entertained for 29 minutes.  I know the game is supposed to mimic the look of a transit map, but the plain, flat, minimalistic shapes were really boring to look at.  Did not at all put me in mind of moving people from place to place.  These type of visuals might work much better on a mobile device than on a full PC display.I was frustrated that I could not choose the type of upgrade I needed at some points.  When I needed tunnels, it only offered me lines and locomotives.  When I needed lines, it only offered my tunnels and carriages.Trains seemed to drive by passengers for no good reason - train was not full, and destination stop was only one or two stations down the track.  This really affected playability negatively at higher levels.Maybe in a few more iterations this might be fun, but not yet...

Posted: November 19, 2015
												For such a simple game, there is a lot of strategy packed into it. Minimalistic graphics prevent distractions from the real purpose of the game: create a subway layout that is efficient. Using only the three starting lines, you must adapt and quickly change based on where new stops open up. Easy to play, difficult to master. I like becauseupon opening the game for the first time, it puts you in control immediately. You must learn on the go. If you want easy to win, this isn't for you. While challenging, it is simple enough that anyone can pick it up in the matter of a few minutes.

Posted: August 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is one of those games that you think will be easy to play and your line will thrive. Although it soon becomes apparent that the task is huge. Each new station that appears, is another problem you have to deal with. You have to manage your resources well to keep your line open. At the end of each round you recieve bonuses like a new train, an additional line or carriage. You decide which, choose wisely or you may just be making your own downfall.You don't need to be a seasoned gamer to get to grasps with this amazing game. Although it's in Early Access, you can see how the game will shape and find new ways to captivate you. The recent addition of Zen Mode keeps you expanding your line for the ultimate Metro.What I love most about this game is that you can not win, only survive the hustle and bustle of the stations for as long as your, hopefully, well planned lines will allow it. The game is aesthetically pleasing - They use the classic coloured lines; like you would see on a metro map. You watch your map expand in realtime as you add more to it. How long can you survive?

Posted: August 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you are looking for a deep management game, this is not it.If you are looking for an intricate transport tycoon follow up game, this is not it.If you are looking for fancy graphics, this is not it.However, if you are looking for a fun puzzler that'll keep you on your toes with reasonable pressure, simple and clean presentation, easy to grasp concept and lots of replayability, this is one of the best games you can get. And if you don't want to be pressurized by the game, you can play the Zen mode, which is a great relaxing timewaster. Simple, clean, intuitive, it's a great way to waste a few hours without even realizing said hours are gone. Bonus points if you are a fan of metro systems, but that isn't required to enjoy this game.Special props to the devs, who are on top of the community and communicate with their customers a lot during the current stage of the game.

Posted: August 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Here is proof you don't need Unity5 to make a GREAT game.It looks a little like the 1970's Atari tennis - but with colour and  A LOT more little blocks moving around. It is essentially a join the dots resource management game - which sounds demeaning but it is not, this is a challenging, fun and addictive game. As the player you get a number of locomotives, carriages, lines and few other goodies with which to build an efficient underground/subway/U-Bahn in a variety of large ciities across Europe, Asia, America and Africa.Passengers mass at stations. They want to go to other stations that match their shape (triangulasr passengers want to go to traingular stations), easy enough but there are quite a few shapes. If to many passengers crowd a station the whole transport system collapses - game over. To move these people you put locomotives on the line, busy lines may mean you have to place extra locos (up tp 4 per line) going in both directions. You only have a limited number of lines and locos which have limited space so.....well you know how these things work. Intersecting train lines, tunnels under rivers and the appearance of specialised stations (hospitals for example) add to the challenge. It's all about getting people out of the system quickly so you can load the next one onto a train and get rid of him to. The problem is the more efficient your train system, the more peole want to use it, so.....well you know how these things work.More stations appear on the map over time, meaning at times a total redesign of track routes etc may be needed.The game is not finished (for example as of writing this, audio is not quite ready), but it is stable and VERY playable - but as I said one of those addicitive 'I'll play just a bit longer" games that ends up filling your evening.

Early Access Review
								If you are looking for a deep management game, this is not it.If you are looking for an intricate transport tycoon follow up game, this is not it.If you are looking for fancy graphics, this is not it.However, if you are looking for a fun puzzler that'll keep you on your toes with reasonable pressure, simple and clean presentation, easy to grasp concept and lots of replayability, this is one of the best games you can get. And if you don't want to be pressurized by the game, you can play the Zen mode, which is a great relaxing timewaster. Simple, clean, intuitive, it's a great way to waste a few hours without even realizing said hours are gone. Bonus points if you are a fan of metro systems, but that isn't required to enjoy this game.Special props to the devs, who are on top of the community and communicate with their customers a lot during the current stage of the game.

												Not an Native English speaker but want to introduce this game to more people who don't know about Chinese. So maybe some strange Chinglish sry.Not everyone would like this game but it is a good game for me. Played 6 hours until I bought this game for a half day.Easy to get how to play this. Just drag your mouse to link stations with line and watch the metro automaticlly working. A person marked by circle want to go to any circle station, so as other shapes. It's addictive but will not spend so much time for a round (such as Sid Meier's Next Turn Civ V) so you can easily stop if you are not trying to get the achivement such as "Ten weeks in Osaka" or what what what in HongkongAnd there're something I must notice to everyone new here. Different maps have different limits, such as London can only put 3 locomotive per line but Osaka can put 4. Without this, there're some special in some maps, such as Osaka have Shinkansen which is a faster locomotive but can only get 1 if you don't choose 2 normal locomotive in a new week, or in Cairo, a locomotive can only take 4 people instead of normally 6.Such a easy-understand game I want to introduce to my parents and I think my dad and mom will also like this game....Eventhought they don't know how to play Minesweeper.9/10, not full mark because I think there can be more maps with much fun and I'm waiting for it  (oh plz don't ask the author to do what you cannot do)  ok ok if I have to give a point without what new things the game should add (in my opinion), then 10/10New: Just read some what Chinese guys wrote, most of them was hoping for Beijing  but I have to say oh not terrible enough Beijing Metro is

Posted: July 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you like a game that you can just jump in and out of, then Mini Metro is certainly a good place to start. When you add the fact that there are many different challenging aspects to the game, it becomes more than just a time-killing game and enters the catagory of pure strategy, And if that isn't enough there's an incredibly statistical post-game analysis focus too, for those that feel the need to find out how to improve on what they've already done. If you also like a game to feel crisp and well made, then this has that feeling in abundance. Even the simplicity of cascading through the menus has a very polished feel.You really can't go wrong with this game, especially for the price. You will not feel cheated at all. In fact, what ever level of gamer you are, you'll feel challenged at some point, guaranteed!

Posted: July 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is extremely addictive! Just when you think you've got the perfect metro network at your hands, one or more stations changes it's type, requiring you to review your lines and train assignments. The only easy moments is right after the game starts with 3 lines and 3 trains, as the weeks progress more types of stations will appear, you will make choices that have direct impact on the next week, but the game will never get easier. Passengers and stations appear faster, and while you try your hardest to keep your main hubs from overcrowding... BAM!! a station on the edge of town escaped your attention, it overcrowds  and it's game over. You wonder how it could have happened but you start the game again, and again. It's fun, I totally recommend this game, it'll give you many hours of strategic planning, a bit of frustration but also fulfilment at completing the Steam Achievements... Good luck!!

Posted: March 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is a delight to play. The objective is simple: get passengers from Point A to Point B while not letting them queue up at choke points. Within this, lies hours and hours of fun. It is like chess - easy to learn the rules, difficult to master.This is one of the few games intended for mobile but works really well on PCPros:Nice learning curveEasy pick up and playAlready at a level where you can play (unlike some other Early Access games)No major / minor bugs: New development is primarily features and polishContinues to get love and effort from the devsWell worth the priceGood variety of maps AND modesIntuitive Minimalist User InterfaceContinues to get updates / polish on a regular basis - improving gameplay, adding new features and complexity - adding a depth to a beautiful game.Cons:Can get a bit repetitive after some hoursEnd game drags a little

Posted: June 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								This might be the most satisfying puzzle game you'll ever play. Particularly if you've ever lived in a place where being able to navigate a complex subway or rail system was an important part of your life, you own it to yourself to pick this up and spend some time with it. The rules are simple, intuitive. You can learn to play in 5 minutes. The resulting strategy is complex and rewarding. It's a game that feels both abstract and practical. This sat in my wishlist for months because of it's early access status. Having bought and played it, I can say it's extremely playable in it's current state. If it wasn't missing the audio you'd never guess it wasn't completely finished.

Posted: June 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								You'll know exactly what I mean when I say that sometimes, you just want a fun, simple game that you can sit down and play for half an hour before daily life resumes. This game fills that role perfectly, artistically, and like it was designed for that express purpose. I find I can't really get invested in this game. I can play for a half-hour before I get bored, but that's fine, because that's really all I NEED to play. I can sit down, beat one of the cities, and resume my daily life.The game has you designing underground metro train systems for major cities, the likes of which include Hong Kong, New York, and Sao Paulo. The colorful little graphics are incredibly soothing, coupled with the calm background music. The game definitely does get frustrating at times, especially when you run out of bridges or your line doesn't work correctly. However, it teaches you to find a way to move past that. It's almost a puzzle game, but not really. If I had to classify it, I'd put it in the casual strategy category.I actually cannot think of any cons that this game has. It is early access, and man, for an early access game, it's amazing. I tend to associate 'early access' with 'broken, unfinished and poorly-optimized', but this goes against all of those stereotypes. I have found exactly zero glitches, and the game doesn't feel unfinished, - perhaps constantly-growing is the right word. I'd love to see more cities, maybe a bus element, I'm not sure. I'll leave that part up to the developers.]Overall, yes, I do recommend this game. And for the modest price of $7.79, why not?

												The last game where I enjoyed playing as much looking at just shapes is Tetris.Basically in this game you guide commuters (depicted in various shapes) to their respective station of the same shape.Pro.Challenging to play as you're limited on resources like trains, how many tunnels you have across river, etc.Not to mention station pop-up every few minutes.Con.Just like playing too much Football Manager, not realistic.Sponsoring this game for respective transport minister won't help him/her much on the job.9/10

Posted: June 26, 2015
												I was hesitating to buy this game and kept it on the wishlist for a longer while, as it seemed expensive. When the Summer Sale came, I decided to buy something I really wanted to play. I felt like a transport sim, but Cities in Motiton didn't get good reviews, while Cities:Skylines were not cheap enough for me. Therefore I had only one choice within my budget and - to my surprise - It seems to be one of the best games for me in my collection!First off, one of my favourite games of all time are: - FTL - a more or less typical rougelike with significant strategy portion - Transport Tycoon / Locomotion series - where one of the main tasks is to build efficient networksCombine the two above and you get MiniMetro :).I'm a busy guy, and I don't have more than a couple of hours every day to play games. Therefore I turn more and more frequently to short games, that I can finish in a day or two, with high replay value. Mini Metro fits this description perfectly. Randomly generated stations are always a challenge (fourth circle or triange station in a condensed area drive me nuts!), while variety of cities encourage to try different strategies. I hope the descriptions will be added soon, although discovering the differences is also a kind of fun.One can look at the game as 100 years of a city growth condensed to 15-30 minutes. There are no resources - every "week" you get something to expand your network. It might seem strange, that you can re-rout your trains in any possible way. That way the creators avoided making the game extremely difficult - fortunately the "extreme" mode exist, adding that piece of realism for hardcore city transport organizers.With such minimalistic design, there is a lot of room for immersion. It's very easy to imagine that triangle and circle station represent every day destinations, like work/home/market. Square is probably a railway station or airport - unique but important. Then there is a bunch of unique ones, that can easily translate to a football stadium, hospital, or other touristic attactions. Even with no sound, you can hear all those crowds, looking at the train with six symbols - each representing a traveller and his destination.One of the best things about this game is the fact, that you are 100% focused on the core - designing the network as efficiently as possible. You don't have to waste more than a few seconds to build the route or add/move trains. If Transport Tycoon was simplified to a white board and lines with rectangles instead of detailed tracks and trains, you could finish the game in a fraction of usual time.Overall - GREAT game! I was not expecting that much from such small game.It's still early access and the devs are working hard to finish it - updates/hotfixes are frequent.FULL VERSION UPDATE: EVEN MORE AWESOME!!!

Posted: September 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: Simple, beautiful, minimal, engrossing, inspiring.Mini Metro is a minimal, surprisingly relaxing, puzzle game. You create tracks between various different types of station in a bid to keep your city rolling smooth and efficient. Your resources are finite, and as your city expands you need to be strategic about how many tunnels you use, where you place junctions, which lines you put your trains on, how many carriages they have and the order in which your lines intersect different station types.Endless mode provides the most zen experience, with no overcrowding on stations, you can just watch your metro grow stress free. A beautifully minimal sound track sets the mood- again, zen. I have no experience playing this before the sound update so can't comment on what it was like before.

Other than that, this game is very well made, and I would easily recommend it.

								What a nice, minimalistic, and addictive casual game!This game is all about building a metro railway system and keeping it working without any station becoming overcrowded. As more stations appear on the map, it's your job to connect them with lines, add more carriages, locomotives and tuinnels as needed. All the time, you'll be short of resources - so it's about allocations the resources wisely and keeping your system working as long a possible. In the first few minutes, this is quite easy, but will get quite hard very soon.Thus game is almost perfect in its minimalistic gameplay and graphics. A good game for a short break from work or for tinkering late at night (using the eye-friendly night color scheme).

Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't know why, but I just love games about making dots move on lines. I own many such games and Mini Metro is the one best right now. The dots on these lines come in different shapes, which is exciting, and the lines can be controlled entirely by the player, with some restrictions. Seeing your dots move efficiently rather than piling up is very gratifying.What makes this game particularly clever, in the dots-on-lines genre, is that the dots represent passengers and the lines connect between stations on real world city geographies. The game can be very challenging, but in a very fun sort of way. There are decisions to make along the way and I feel like these are very important decisions. Don't forget you can always remove and rebuild lines when you find yourself struggling. What was most efficient at the start of the game may not be the most efficient halfway through.I would recommend this game. There are bugs, and it's Early Access, but it's fun.

Posted: June 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a game that I will play for the rest of my life. I really love the originality and simplicity of the concept. The user interface is nice. If I were to mention any complaint it would only be that a few of the updates seem to be a step in the wrong direction, although they don't ruin the playability of the game. Thank you, makers of this wonderful subway management game.

Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game isn't so much a transportation network simulation as it is a subtle puzzle game. The key to sucess is to not overload your lines with the same symbols next to each other because that will cause stations to be backed up. Make sure to stagger the symbols! (triangle-circle-triangle is good, triangle-triangle-circle is bad.) This is easier said than done because many times you will have no choice but to have four circles in a row on one line.The second secret is always retool your lines as you play the level. More stations are added as the game plays out, and you will find what worked for the first 300 passengers all of a sudden isn't as efficient and you have to clear the lines and re-lay them out for the next 300.There's a lot of strategy in this game, from how you lay out the map to what bonuses you get every level. I've just sat here and played through all levels for the past five hours and even went back and replayed a couple of early levels that I didn't do so well because I hadn't figured out the system yet. This is a fun game!This game is low on flash and high on substance, it's a must have for anyone who loves puzzle strategy games!

Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't know why, but I just love games about making dots move on lines. I own many such games and Mini Metro is the one best right now. The dots on these lines come in different shapes, which is exciting, and the lines can be controlled entirely by the player, with some restrictions. Seeing your dots move efficiently rather than piling up is very gratifying.What makes this game particularly clever, in the dots-on-lines genre, is that the dots represent passengers and the lines connect between stations on real world city geographies. The game can be very challenging, but in a very fun sort of way. There are decisions to make along the way and I feel like these are very important decisions. Don't forget you can always remove and rebuild lines when you find yourself struggling. What was most efficient at the start of the game may not be the most efficient halfway through.I would recommend this game. There are bugs, and it's Early Access, but it's fun.

I've played through evey city at least once on every mode, and I've come back multiple times to replay when the layout has been redesigned or they've added new features and such -- and it just keeps getting better and better, without getting (noticeably) more complex to play.

Posted: April 2, 2016
												The minimalist design is really beautiful, and the simple gameplay lends itself to trying a lot of strategies. Stations are represented as one of a number of shapes with passengers looking to be routed to a different shape, so lines need to be designed to effectively carry people around the network. This abstraction nicely mirrors the real world, with circles equivalent to commuter stops, squares as central hubs, and unique shapes representing individual points of interest. Somehow this game succeeds at being simultaneously relaxing and stressful as hell.
