Posted: June 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is a strategy game with a very minimalistic interface and set of rules.You're a designer of a city's subway lines, and you have to keep passengers flowing through stations as they continue to pop up all over a city. Every week, you earn an additional train engine and one of two items, that could be an additional car (holds more passengers), a tunnel to navigate through waterways, a new line (with a maximum number allowed per city).The object is to move as many passengers as possible, without letting any passenger wait at a station for too long.Though still not ready for prime time, what is in the game is well-built and very challenging. The best laid plans constantly need to be changed to fit around passenger needs. You can't rest while the city grows around you.If you're a fan of train, simulation or strategy games, I highly recommend this title. If you just want a casual challenge and like minimalism, I would also recommend this game. Try it out.

Posted: June 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								This might be the most satisfying puzzle game you'll ever play. Particularly if you've ever lived in a place where being able to navigate a complex subway or rail system was an important part of your life, you own it to yourself to pick this up and spend some time with it. The rules are simple, intuitive. You can learn to play in 5 minutes. The resulting strategy is complex and rewarding. It's a game that feels both abstract and practical. This sat in my wishlist for months because of it's early access status. Having bought and played it, I can say it's extremely playable in it's current state. If it wasn't missing the audio you'd never guess it wasn't completely finished.

Posted: June 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								What a nice, minimalistic, and addictive casual game!This game is all about building a metro railway system and keeping it working without any station becoming overcrowded. As more stations appear on the map, it's your job to connect them with lines, add more carriages, locomotives and tuinnels as needed. All the time, you'll be short of resources - so it's about allocations the resources wisely and keeping your system working as long a possible. In the first few minutes, this is quite easy, but will get quite hard very soon.Thus game is almost perfect in its minimalistic gameplay and graphics. A good game for a short break from work or for tinkering late at night (using the eye-friendly night color scheme).

Posted: October 5, 2015

It's relaxing to play the game, true, with its now-existant soundscaping that really is quite lovely and relaxing, its pretty, smooth lines, and the constant motion of the subway cars. The whole setup is calm and relaxing.However, the game's pace quickly becomes frantic, a race against the clock. You WILL lose. The only question is of how quickly you will do so. It's a nice game to play in short periods of time between doing work things, or when you simply need to wind down, but it is genuinely challenging when it wants to be. I like that.

Early Access Review
								I was confused when I first opened the game, there's no initial tutorial but it's fairly intuitive. I saw this critique before and I think it bears repeating, sometimes the same generation creates the same shape in a cluster which creates more back up than beneficial to the game. There's a high number of circle locations that appear and few squares that are generated which makes it incredibly difficult to make an effective line if i'm connecting a string of circle stations together. I'd like to see the station generation balanced a bit differently from where it currently is. I've enjoyed the game as a calming puzzle, it's relaxing with the limited color pallet and the clean design. I've already recommended it to people.I look forward to seeing this game completed and how things might be tweaked from early access to full release.

Posted: April 21, 2016
												I have played very little of this game (to date), but it has been sat on my Wishlist for 2 years, and I have known about it since just after the idea for Mini Metro was conceived.First of all, go buy this game.It is incredibly cheap for infinite amount of fun. It's like the PC equivalent of a good mobile game. No wait-timers. No microtransactions. Nothing fiddly. Just a simple concept, that is executed to perfection.I would however, recommend having something else to do whilst you play. Maybe watch Netflix. Maybe have Sky Go on in the background. Maybe listen to a podcast. Maybe watch some YouTube! Maybe buy all your friends copies of this fantastic little game.The reason I say it's fantastic and that everyone should buy it, is because I believe everyone could get something out of this. Whether it be a way to relax, a fun puzzle game, an intense management game, or a way to kill time, I think anyone and everyone can, and should, get some enjoyment from this wonderful little ball of trains.

Posted: February 8, 2016
												Simple: Draw metro tracks and choose how many trains go to each. No budgets, no construction time, etc.Calming: In normal mode, you lose once the metro stations start getting backed up. This prevents the game from getting hectic which makes it a nice game for destressing. It also has a minimalist interface with a calm sound scheme.Complex: While you could play it as a casual game, it's not merely a "casual" game. When I first started, I played it like a casual game. "New station pops up? I'll connect the nearest metro line to it. It'd look a lot prettier if the line was more symmetrical." You can do that, but you score in the bottom 25%. Then I realized, there is actually a ton of strategic depth to this game despite its casual appearance. Each time I play I realize new strategic factors in things that seemed like they didn't matter before. Now I'm in the top 10%. So, I think it's fair to saying it's more than a casual game. You can play it "casually" but you can also play it "seriously", analyzing every tiny detail.

Early Access Review
								I bought this on a whim during the Steam summer sale because I was intrigued. The simplistic gameplay couldn't possibly appeal to someone who is so easily taken in by massive, engaging worlds in RPG games, right? Wrong. I need to do my homework for grad school, but the random little shapes of Paris obviously need me to provide their transportation to a matching shape!Sarcasm aside, I actually am greatly enjoying this game. I know it's in Beta, and accepted that when I made the decision to purchase, so I understand glitches and bumpiness and all that. Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								That feeling during Tetris when the bricks are stacked too high and you're scrambling to reduce the pack before it reaches the ceiling and becomes GAME OVER.That feeling is what makes Mini Metro a great game.Every game starts out incredibly simple, but very quickly begins to spiral out of control.Amazing puzzle game with no tangible solution or result.Just a struggle against the pressure of more passengers and more stations, with not enough trains, capacity or train lines.Eventually, you fail. A station somewhere explodes from overcapacity.Restart/Continue/Quit appear on screen.You press continue...And the game keeps going. With the same map.Exactly where you failed.Except now, you can focus on improving efficiency, with no fear of failure.Different locations provide varying parameters for the game experience. Hong Kong has interchanges, Paris generates more bridges, Osoka has bullet trains.Endless mode lets you jump straight into the efficiency drive, just connecting stations between lines with not much pressure.Extreme mode challenges the player with one slight, realisitic modification. Every track is permanent. Pressure overload.Very easy game to jump in to and enjoy. Difficult game to master.One of my top 10 games of 2015 so far.PROS:Simple game mechanicsWonderful display and designTension, oh boy, that tensionVariety of modes/locationsCONS:No audio (yet)Can complete all the areas and modes in a few hours8/10

								Mini metro is a simple yet challenging puzzle game that's best played in short, half hour bursts. It's good value for money if you enjoy exploring the different ways you can try to play the game and make your own strategy... It can be addicting at times! The only fault I can find is that it may be too simple for a few people, but that's about it.What I best like about the game: How the simplicity of the game means anyone can make their own strategy and experement. Making each map more unique (for example changing the design of a locomotive for each map)Overall: 9/10. Simple, fun and addicting.

Posted: September 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's a pure strategy title and by fully embracing their limits it does everything right. The goal is simple, transporting little passenger blocks to their desired stations. The UI is simple, dragging subway paths along the stops and adding carts on existing lines. At the start of every week you can choose between one of two upgrades. That's basically it. The depth? Surprisingly complex. With the ever increasing number of stations that you have to connect to your network and the ability to add new lines, the game gets ever more challenging. To solve this you can choose many different strategies, and even derive from real world subways. Star shaped, circle, checkerboard? Everything is possible (though not always efficient).The game is still in development and lacks certain important features, such as sound. If you don't mind you should buy it right now! Otherwise it is planned to be released in November 2014.

Posted: July 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a very fun little RTS/puzzle/sim/whatever game.  It's very simple and great if you just need to kill a few minutes, but it also feels surprisingly deep.  I've done very well on most of the leaderboards, but I still feel like I'm only just starting to grasp the strategy of it.  It's well worth the 7 bucks if you like games like this.  (Although, I honestly can't think of very many games quite like this.)  Just make sure to bring your own music, because as of writing this, there is still none in the game.

Posted: July 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I started playing this game back when the beta number was in the single digits, and I have been very happy with how the development has progressed. The more recent changes (individualized cities being a huge change for the better) have been great without changing the game from its core.You lead the development of a single city's subway infrastructure to transport its citizens (circles, squares, triangles, and the like) to their desired station. Play starts off slowly, with passengers spawning quite slowly and you having a ton of resources at your disposal. Play difficulty (on the standard settings) quickly ramps up through the weeks to the point where you are just hanging on to your non-crowded stations...or you just lose because four stations go over the edge.You can also take the relaxing, almost theraputic route where you go for system efficiency. In this case, your upgrades come after reaching efficiency milestones instead of each week, but the goal is more relaxing to obtain.I'm looking forard to the soon-to-be-included soundtrack, which will finally make this a complete game (as much as I did like listening to movie soundtracks while playing).

Posted: July 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is amazing value for money, for me at least. I have played 15+ hours so far and this game does something that not many other early access games do for me, it keeps bringing me back to see what’s new every month. It’s great for podcasts or just being in the background while you do something else in endless mode and also great if you want to really knuckle down and strategize. The art style is ok, nothing unique for a minimalistic game, but definitely not dull. The is no music and it has been promised since the game came out. To be honest, my play time will probably double with an amazing soundtrack. The leaderboard aspect of the game is great, should be a standard in most games in my opinion. The unlock system is actually pretty cool, they use the same formula for each tier of unlock, but the fact the dev realises the difficulty level of each map by the amount of things you have to accomplish really shows how much testing has happened behind the scenes and how much they pay attention to the data and the community which is refreshing to say the least nowadays. So I’m going to give this game a 7/10 purely because lack of music, otherwise a solid 9/10.

Posted: October 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Each playthrough starts out perfectly innocently.  It's reassuring.  Almost boring.  A little voice in the back of my head tells me that I'm laying foundations for what will come next, and that it's important to get this right, but the ease of redesigning my entire system at this point in the game tells me that the voice is lying.  The week ends, I get a new locomotive, and choose one of options to go with it.Somehow, by week five, my nice, neat train system has started to turn into a spider's-web of cross-connections and long loops.  I need to add a new station to the main loop, which means disconnecting three stations, then reconnecting them in a different sequence.  Of course, now that I've done that, it should reduce the pressure on that line and mean that I'm dropping passengers off more often, which should improve the overall capacity.  Unfortunately, I didn't notice a new station opening up on the other side of the map, and it's critically overcrowded.  Game over.Mini Metro is a roguelike action-puzzle game where the central mechanic is designing a train network.  It's trickier than it looks, and if it gets its strangely compelling hooks into you, it may drive you insane.  Enough time wasted - I need to fire it back up and see if I can work out a better way of dealing with those annoying suburban regions where nobody wants to get off, and everybody wants to get on....

Posted: October 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is something special. It's ostentatiously a minimalist route optimisation game, but it's much more sinister.Set in what can only be a post scarcity technological singularity, stations are created in days without prior permission, and with arbitrary locations, and you must optimise train routes to shuttle the lumbering masses of humanity towards their destination no matter what, lest your train station spontaneously combust from the irate hordes. Yet these routes don't take years to construct, mere hours in fact. Tonnes and tonnes of rail and infrastructure put into place with scant regard for whoever lives in its way. Yet your advancement depends on either your efficiency or number of passengers delivered - a brutal commentary on the dog eat dog world we live in today.Truly, Mini Metro can be descrived as a deconstructive commentary of our modern living.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Easily one of my favourite puzzle games.  The game's focus on efficiency goes beyond the gameplay itself with a minimalist, unobtrusive UI that provides a maximum of information and means of control with a minimum of clutter. The "Classic Underground Map" aesthetic is carried off perfectly by the developers, with plenty of thought evidently going into even seemingly minor points such as the colour palette used for different subway lines. With new maps and new challenges facing players after each patch, the game has excellent replay value.Continuing on the theme of efficiency, the game is also a compact one, weighing in at 200MB of disk space. It is also well-optimised, allowing even weaker, older systems to run the game with acceptable framerates and without any serious reliability issues. Multiple-OS compatibility is also a pleasant plus.Recommended even at its standard price, this game offers excellent value for money when it is on sale.

Posted: January 28, 2016
												I wish ratings were more of a yes/no but I just can't recommend this game if you are looking for a transport simThat being said, Mini Metro is beautiful, simple graphics resemble infographics... generated music depending on what is happening in the game leads to a very pleasant initial experience...but once you start playing the game you start realizing where Mini Metro doesn't quite make it...things like dots just want to go to the nearest station with the appropriate shape which doesn't really make any sense in a simulation... dots will never go "cross town"... if it weren't for "special" stations I don't think you would even have to connect your lines together if laid out properlythe stations seem to appear completely randomly, sometimes making efficient motion easy, sometimes making it virtually impossible...populations will sometimes rise steadily, or sometimes simply explode leading to a quick, unavoidable failure...reinforcements are just based on time (one in game week) and are too few and far between... the efficiency mode is much nicer but that will eventually max out and then you have essentially just run out of game...I hope the developer continues to work on this game since I really do love what they have so far, it just needs some tweaking

Posted: August 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								There's something inherently calming about joining the dots and creating order - and Mini Metro capitalises on this beautifully. Gorgeous, minimal and uncluttered design, lovely bright colours and simple shapes are the order of the day. Shaped stations pop up on the white landscape, requiring you to join them together with lines. As you do, passengers appear at them, demanding to get to other stations.The system that deals with moving passengers about, especially when to and when not to pick them up and which interchanges to drop them at seems, even in this 'early access' build, to be flawless. Short of the missing sound and music (which I can't wait for) and the so-called Scenic and Rush Hour modes (which seem to be Zen and Extreme in the version I have here) this is already a fantastic little game. Bonus points for having a night mode as well.For fear of cluttering up the minimalism I'd like to be able to name stops  for my own reference or just for fun, but otherwise, I can't wait for the last finishing touches.

Posted: August 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								$7 might seem like much for what is practically a iOS game, but the dedication and constant updates from the developer really make this a game to try out. Even The Walking Dead was ported to mobile, so it's not like this game doesn't have a place here. Mini Metro allows you to run your own metro system on minimalistic maps based on real cities such as London, Paris, and New York City. It's really just a drag-and-drop formula, but the more you play the more challenging it gets. The game doesn't end until your metro gets overcrowded and shut down, but this can even take a while for the simpliest of simpletons. Not even an hour in and I could feel the potential this game has. Pros (because a lot of people enjoy that):-The most casual, yet fun gameplay-Variety of cities and maps to play on-Leaderboards to make you feel bad as a beginner-Both Night mode and Colorblind mode for visually impaired people sneaking on their PCs at midnight-Fairly open settings (Graphics, resolution, etc.)-Cities in Motion 2 for people like me who can't run Cities in Motion 2Cons:-The most casual, yet simple gameplay-No music (as of August 21, 2014 [8/21/14])-No train bombing scenarios-No inspirational get-man-out-of-train-tracks scenarios-No scenarios

Posted: August 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								A game with great potential.Well I would say that, presently speaking, this game is kinda boring actually. Controls are simple, just use your mouse to draw line between dots (representing stations). If any station gets overcrowded you lose the game. It's really about planning lines ONLY, unlike other sim games like SimCity of Cities in Motion where you can choose to place your own stations within the city. (In this game there is no image of the city AT ALL.) Here you dont get to choose where you build your stations. They pop-up randomly.  DO NOT buy this game and think that you're playing SimCity.  If the developer manages to add-in some other modes (like sandbox, where there is no ending with overcrowding), the game can be a great time-killer.It's a 2-D game so great for low-end PCs.I would give it thumbs up just for the possibility of future development.

Posted: November 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very fun puzzle game that represents a masterpiece of simplicity.It provides a very cerebral challange because there are so many possibilities and strategies, and all of them have advantages and disadvantages. You find yourself constantly trying to figure out the best way of planning. There is a great deal of strategy for such a simple concept.Not yet fully developed, but even in its current state it's fantastic. At present, there is no music and are no win conditions, but if you put on your own music it can be such a cozy atmosphere, and the lack of win condition, similar to tetris (it just gets harder and harder until you lose), provides a really addictive need to create an even better system. Simple to play, difficult to master, impossible to put down. Can't wait to see the final product.

Posted: August 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								A classic game in the making. Having played only an hour and a half at the moment I can see myself loosing much more time to this game. While the lack of music is sad, being Early Access, I can't wait for the soundtrack to be added on. All in all, this is no train sim, it is a frustratingly fun strategists dream which challenges your abilities each time you play through and there is no forgiveness for even the slightest oversight. That being said, I would have liked a little tutorial that would have explained that when a new station appears on an existing line it becomes a place where trains blissfully roll by. Therefore, you must either redraw the entire line to include the new station or add it to another line. Graphically, the simplistic design is really quite beautiful and as time goes on you start to admire the mess of lines that begin to splay out as you try to balance length of lines and coverage. All in all, a great game and I highly recommend picking this game up while it is at a very reasonable price. On a lighter note, I now take my hat off to every Transport Minister past and present.

Posted: June 3, 2016
												This  game has that simplicity and addictive "I'll play just one more" nature to it that all the classics (Tetris, Angry Birds, etc.). When you first run the game, you think it is doing a tutorial, and you are right, but then you realize you have also actually started your first real game. The learning curve is gradual and fun as the first game you play teaches you how to play. I have only played the London map so far, and I feel like I could play it over and over and try different techniques to figure out the best strategies--I cannot imagine how much more fun this will be when I try the other maps like Paris and Berlin.The user interface is clean and fun to look at--it uses the actual metro symbology of simple lines and colors and connectors to actually provide the graphics for the game and interface, all in one. Genius decision. As an added perk, you can save your games after you finish as screenshots and animated GIFs! Such a fun game!Some might critidize the lack of multiplayer, but as quick as the games are, you could make it multi by challenging a friend to the same map and watching them play. Even watching a game is mesmerizing!UPDATE AFTER 9 HOURS OF PLAYThis game is so awesome. I come back to it almost every day and play a round or two. I am trying not to go on to the next map until I have done 1,000 passengers...but this broke down when I hit Hong Kong, where I cannot get more than 500 or so. So hard! I went ahead and went on and lowered my standard to 500+ passengers per map before I go on, and so far I can hit 1,000 passengers on all of them up to Osaka, which I just played today--Osaka, which has a really fast train engine on it! I did not know this game had different engines later in the maps! This made an already addictive, fun, challenging, innovative, elegant game that much better! So good. When this comes out on Android, I will buy it again so I can play on my phone and tablet!

Hopefully, some audio will be added; for such a game, I believe a simple audio track much alike white noise would be perfect in creating a calming atmosphere. Posted: November 29, 2015
												I've always had this need to optimize things... and graph theory was one of my majors at university. Needless to say, I love this game. It's one of those rare ones that can be picked up whenever you just have a little time and quickly played as well as when you have lots of time to beat a high score ;). The game is simple to comprehend but has extreme depth and requires a lot of foresight when planning routes (or the will to reorganize your whole network if things start to get ugly later).The moment I saw the first screenshots of this game I knew I needed to have it - lucky for us all it turned out that the creators knew how to deliver a great implementation, too!

Posted: February 4, 2016
A simple concept executed well...'Take passengers from one station to another before stations overcrowd and shut down' sounds so simple.  Add in the different shapes (types of passenger) and per-city limitations on the number of lines, trains, carriages and tunnels - and suddenly a simple concept becomes a very tactical strategy puzzle.The Steam Achievements have been well thought out - the first tier are pretty easy (Deliver X passengers in Y), the second tier vary from moderate to fiendish (for example, "Deliver 1500 passengers in Auckland using no more than two tunnels" has a 0.3% success rate so far) and will certainly result in some frustration... before you start another game anyway!It's a game that can be played for 15 minutes, or for a few hours at a time.  As well as the normal game mode, the endless mode allows you to focus on optimal configurations (as stations cannot overcrowd) and the extreme mode forces you to think even further ahead as you cannot revert changes!The random nature of each game is a mixed blessing - it provides replay value but occasionally will give you games that are frustratingly difficult (such as large clusters of circle stations together).  Thankfully those levels can be predicted early on so you can abandon them and start again if you wish.£6.99 / €9.99 / $9.99 might be towards the top end of pricing for a game such as this, but it offers considerable replay value.  Additionally, the developer provides a link to his Trello board in the news updates, which provides insight into what new features may be coming in the future.

Posted: May 20, 2016
												This game is pretty fun, If you really like subways or HRT maps you will probably enjoy this. It is important to note that this game is not like a tycoon where you upgrade and build things where you want. Instead you are forced to make the most strategic routes for your shapes. Also Game durations are short (5-15mins). However, there is a god like mode where there is no time limit. Because the game is so short, there is an emphasis on your score which you can compare to others and friends. The problem with this game is it can be repetitive after a while. It's worth 5$ - 10$ USD in my opinion.

Posted: May 21, 2016
												Graphics: Mini Metro is a very minimalistic game, and the visuals are pleasing to look at. The game is not taxing at all, as a result of the simple appearance. Beyond that, there isn't much more to say.Audio: The game also has some very satisfying sounds to accompany the visuals. Unfortunately, the music can get very repetitive, but the sound effects are great.Gameplay: The gameplay is quite simple, but enjoyable nonetheless. The different levels don't add a huge amount of variation to the gameplay, but there are some different details to spice things up. This is a puzzle game at heart, but it can be played very casually, and it's nice just to have something simple to click on to pass some time.TL;DR: This is a great and simple little game that's excellent for playing casually, especially if it can be found at a low price.

Posted: August 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you're looking for a difficult-to-master strategy game, this is pretty solid. If, however, you're looking for a mass transit sim ... this is not it. Once you figure out key elements of maximizing efficiency, you begin to realize that the real-world logic behind the layout of the world's metros need not apply. Thinking of a radial design enclosed by a circle line? It'll only last if the sequence of shapes makes sense. Ultimately that's where the game lost its 'sim' appeal for me. Nevertheless it's a satisfying puzzler that can embrace many different tactical approaches.

Posted: August 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is one of those games that you think will be easy to play and your line will thrive. Although it soon becomes apparent that the task is huge. Each new station that appears, is another problem you have to deal with. You have to manage your resources well to keep your line open. At the end of each round you recieve bonuses like a new train, an additional line or carriage. You decide which, choose wisely or you may just be making your own downfall.You don't need to be a seasoned gamer to get to grasps with this amazing game. Although it's in Early Access, you can see how the game will shape and find new ways to captivate you. The recent addition of Zen Mode keeps you expanding your line for the ultimate Metro.What I love most about this game is that you can not win, only survive the hustle and bustle of the stations for as long as your, hopefully, well planned lines will allow it. The game is aesthetically pleasing - They use the classic coloured lines; like you would see on a metro map. You watch your map expand in realtime as you add more to it. How long can you survive?

Posted: March 11
												I don't have many hours in this game on Steam, mostly because I have it on mobile and I often play it when I'm waiting for appointments and sitting in traffic. I have, however, still played enough on Steam to know that there's no true difference between the two versions.This game is an example of a casual game done right. It's a game you can just pick up and play. You don't learn through lengthy text tutorials, but rather through visual cues and your own personal experimentation. It's fun and relaxing, but also presents a challenge. Its difficulty scales over time, and eventually, you will lose.This game is a must for any casual gamer, but I recommend it to gamers of any description. Everyone needs to relax sometimes - even the most hardcore gamer. It's like having a little sand garden on your desk, but with a really chill soundtrack accompanying it.

								Pros: Simply addicitve and stright forward fun. I.E. Rubix cube, Tetris, Sokoban and MIni Metro. I'm always working toward beating my own scores. Even got friends interested in it. Cons: I have latency or memory leak in the scenic mode when I get to about 60 passengers. Odd this doesn't occur even on commuter mode with 900 passengers. Hopefully there is a fix in place for this one day.Sidebar: Maybe we can have an emergency bus route we can use once a day for "emergency" situations? The guy going to to pick his kid up at school (left out in the rain) called my boss and got me in trouble, Not my problem he shoulda gave the kid an umbrella. - jeesh.

Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is, hands-down, the finest first-play experience I have ever had from a casual game.  Mini Metro is an outstanding example of perfection in minimalism, and a resounding lesson that gameplay trumps all.  As of this date, there is no music, and the graphics are simple transit system line art.  In short, you could have knocked this out on a VIC-20 in your basement-- if you'd been this much of a genius.The concept is brilliant, and the execution is perfect-- but this is still early access at this point, so there's a bit of a level shortage.  That's alleviated somewhat by the several subtly-- but importantly-- different play modes.Also, there are not a lot of upgrades at this point.  There are only three or four limited, important resources, and they're all really major.  A handful of more subtle, minor-tweak upgrades would make things a bit more visually interesting, as well as giving you a few things to tinker with when you're waiting to see how well a major change plays out.Nonetheless, this is absolutely the best casual game I've played in years.  Highly recommended, and definitely worth the money.  The only real question is whether you will also want it on your phone or tablet, where I expect touch-and-drag would only add to the fun.

Posted: August 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								$7 might seem like much for what is practically a iOS game, but the dedication and constant updates from the developer really make this a game to try out. Even The Walking Dead was ported to mobile, so it's not like this game doesn't have a place here. Mini Metro allows you to run your own metro system on minimalistic maps based on real cities such as London, Paris, and New York City. It's really just a drag-and-drop formula, but the more you play the more challenging it gets. The game doesn't end until your metro gets overcrowded and shut down, but this can even take a while for the simpliest of simpletons. Not even an hour in and I could feel the potential this game has. Pros (because a lot of people enjoy that):-The most casual, yet fun gameplay-Variety of cities and maps to play on-Leaderboards to make you feel bad as a beginner-Both Night mode and Colorblind mode for visually impaired people sneaking on their PCs at midnight-Fairly open settings (Graphics, resolution, etc.)-Cities in Motion 2 for people like me who can't run Cities in Motion 2Cons:-The most casual, yet simple gameplay-No music (as of August 21, 2014 [8/21/14])-No train bombing scenarios-No inspirational get-man-out-of-train-tracks scenarios-No scenarios

Posted: August 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								A game with great potential.Well I would say that, presently speaking, this game is kinda boring actually. Controls are simple, just use your mouse to draw line between dots (representing stations). If any station gets overcrowded you lose the game. It's really about planning lines ONLY, unlike other sim games like SimCity of Cities in Motion where you can choose to place your own stations within the city. (In this game there is no image of the city AT ALL.) Here you dont get to choose where you build your stations. They pop-up randomly.  DO NOT buy this game and think that you're playing SimCity.  If the developer manages to add-in some other modes (like sandbox, where there is no ending with overcrowding), the game can be a great time-killer.It's a 2-D game so great for low-end PCs.I would give it thumbs up just for the possibility of future development.

Posted: January 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just a crazy simple, beautiful, extremely polished strategy game.Place metro lines to connect stations that randomly appear as you play.  That's basically it.  You have a limited number of lines, a limited number trains and cars to place on your lines, and a limited number of tunnels to cross water, each of which you recieve more of as you play.  You can place and delete and rearrange your lines and trains as much as you want for no cost (and there is a tactical pause).  All you have to do is keep getting polygonal people to their polygonal destinations smoothly as long as you can, while the number of stations and passengers keeps increasing.Although the game is still in early access, this is really an incredibly polished game (the only thing missing is sound, which I don't mind).  It looks clean an modern and beautiful, it has a lovely UI and menu system... it's extremely clear and easy to use.  I've spent several hours playing it so far, and I definitely intend to play more... it is a great casual game - easy to pick up, with short self-contained sessions - but it also has some real depth.  You can put a lot of thought into your metro designs, or you can just throw something down and watch what happens.  It's quite flexible in terms of ways to play.  Each map/level/city also offers unique constraints and layouts (semi randomized each time of course), and the difficulty of the levels ranges from hold-my-hand to crushingly difficult, giving you access to all of them immediately, so you can explore your ability and comfort level from the beginning, and aspire to those harder cities.The only negative thing I can think of to say about the game is that I wouldn't want to sit and play it for hours straight.  It's more of a pick-up put-down game.  Also, there is no tutorial, and while the UI is relatively straight forward, understanging the princples of the game might take you a couple minutes and/or google searches.  Hopefully a tutorial will be added soon :)Highly recommended!  I think this has a lot of appeal for a lot of different types of people.

Posted: June 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game isn't so much a transportation network simulation as it is a subtle puzzle game. The key to sucess is to not overload your lines with the same symbols next to each other because that will cause stations to be backed up. Make sure to stagger the symbols! (triangle-circle-triangle is good, triangle-triangle-circle is bad.) This is easier said than done because many times you will have no choice but to have four circles in a row on one line.The second secret is always retool your lines as you play the level. More stations are added as the game plays out, and you will find what worked for the first 300 passengers all of a sudden isn't as efficient and you have to clear the lines and re-lay them out for the next 300.There's a lot of strategy in this game, from how you lay out the map to what bonuses you get every level. I've just sat here and played through all levels for the past five hours and even went back and replayed a couple of early levels that I didn't do so well because I hadn't figured out the system yet. This is a fun game!This game is low on flash and high on substance, it's a must have for anyone who loves puzzle strategy games!

Posted: November 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a great little game, a simple to learn strategy/puzzle game that has that whole "one more go" aspect.All you need to do is link your different stations together and make sure the stations don't get too busy.  Yes you'll earn extra trains, extra carriages and extra lines.  But the whole game still comes down to the simple goal of linking your stations together.   You start with three stations and it seems an overly easy task but as the station start to increase so too does the difficulty and you find your metro system falling apart as you try to figure out the best way to connect them all.Thankfully there's the option to hit Pause, then delete all your lines and have a wee think about a new tactic, before finding that it works even worse than your previous layout.  Lots of different maps to play on too to give a bit of variety.As it's Early Access there are some things missing, no sound for example.  But the game idea is there and works perfectly and it can already keep you coming back over and over in it's current state.  It's well worth buying, especially considering how cheap it is.

Posted: June 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't know why, but I just love games about making dots move on lines. I own many such games and Mini Metro is the one best right now. The dots on these lines come in different shapes, which is exciting, and the lines can be controlled entirely by the player, with some restrictions. Seeing your dots move efficiently rather than piling up is very gratifying.What makes this game particularly clever, in the dots-on-lines genre, is that the dots represent passengers and the lines connect between stations on real world city geographies. The game can be very challenging, but in a very fun sort of way. There are decisions to make along the way and I feel like these are very important decisions. Don't forget you can always remove and rebuild lines when you find yourself struggling. What was most efficient at the start of the game may not be the most efficient halfway through.I would recommend this game. There are bugs, and it's Early Access, but it's fun.

Posted: March 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm not usually a fan of early access games, but the minimalism present in this game really appealed to me. When I first played a couple of months ago, I was a bit disappointed with the lack of variety. There were only a couple of maps, which all played very similarly, and Rush Hour mode was not yet finished. When I started playing again recently, I was pleased with what the developers had done. More than double the maps were added, all which now play quite differently from each other, and Rush Hour mode was complete. At this point, it would seem the game is complete (minus the lack of audio), but it seems the developers still have a few things in mind.Overall the game is very easy to pick up an play. It's simple, relaxing and, despite being somewhat slow-paced, very challenging. I'm still not certain if you can actually "win" a game, but that doesn't keep me from trying. Highly recommended.

								I have played this game since the very early Alpha versions before it was on Steam.  This game has successfully captured the fun of creating a subway map.  The game looks like a subway map. Posted: December 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Public Transport can be horrible. Especially trains. Most people say: "I can do a much better job at that!" Well, lets see if you canThis is a game where you control the London underground, exept it's not always in London. It could be Auckland, New York or even Paris! The developers - Dinosaur Polo - are always open for ideas, so if you don't like something (how?) it would be fixed.The controls can be a bit dodgy, removing a station for example isn't as easy as it sounds. You get upgrades every Sunday which allow you to:Add a carriage (max 3)Add a train ( max 3 I believe)Increase the amount of tunnels/bridgesAdd a line ( max 7, start with 3)and more!The game comes with 2 modes, with one coming soon:CommuterScenicRush hour (to be added)Commuter is the normal, standard, frustrating gameScenic, you can't lose. You get points by how many passengers use your metro per weekRush hour will probably be a ery intense commuter modeIn the game we have four types of stations:Circle (common)Triangle (uncommon)Square (rare)Special (very rare)Even though some are rarer then others, you will get at least one of these each game. The map is randomly generated however, so you never know where they will spawn.That should finish my review. I do reccomend this game and rating out of 100 would be:                                                                   97.5/100

Posted: February 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								First and foremost, Mini Metro is one of the most minimalistic games I have ever played. Everything from the design of the menus to the actual gameplay itself is super minimalistic, which makes the game easy on the eyes and overall a relaxing experience. The game comes with 3 modes, Communter, Scenic, and Rush Hour, each with their own spin on the theme of delivering "passengers" to the station they would like to go to. But here is the catch, these "passengers" have a destination designated by a shape. That means if you have a circle passenger, and there are 3 circle stations on the map, then that passenger has 3 possible destinations. The system will obviously take the passenger on the route that is fastest to a circle station, but that makes the game not a "one passenger-one destination" sim, but rather a route building puzzle game.I highly recommend this for its relaxing gameplay, and would definitely recommend the game to my friends looking for a fun little casual game to burn some time on. However, if you are looking for a more hardcore simulation style transportation style game, this might not fit your expectations, but you will definitely still have fun!Good luck and game on!

Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
Disclaimer: This review is for the Early Access version as of February 15, 2015. This review may be edited or deleted as Early Access progresses or when the game releases.Review: As a really young kid, I loved the New York City subway because we rode it every day, and I loved looking at the maps. Sometimes I would even draw out my own station maps for the hell of it. Mini Metro takes what I did as a kid and makes a really enthralling yet really difficult puzzle game out of it.Mini Metro starts off with giving you three stations. You have to connect subway lines between these stations to transport passengers. That's it, though. You click and drag and boom, line complete and subway moving. Soon enough, as the city grows, more and more cities will require subway service and you'll have to manage your limited number of lines as efficiently as possible. Don't forget that you're limited on the number of tunnels/bridges you can make over waterways! The puzzle gameplay is really solid - I can't say if it's unique, but it's definitely sticking out as a favorite of mine.The best part of Mini Metro is the visuals. The game almost looks exactly like the modern subway maps you see in New York City, London, etc. and the vibrant, unique colors make it easy to distinguish between lines. There's even a night mode, for anyone who would get blinded by the white backdrop.There's no audio at all, which allows you to use your favorite media player in conjunction with the game. However, procedural audio is a planned feature, so we'll see what comes of it!Honestly, this is a puzzle game that I would recommend to anyone. It's fun, it's challenging, and it's vibrant.

Posted: April 3
												This is a great game to play to relax to. The music is atmospheric and soothing. The gameplay mostly lets you watch your creation at work. The graphics are simple yet easy on the eyes.If I were to have a problem with it, it would be the fact that new stations and problem stations aren't easier to notice. The gong of a new station appearing is often lost in the hustle and bustle, and the chirp of a station being overcrowded doesn't exactly tell you where, if there are several one might get lost in the shuffle.I don't normally strive for achievements, but the ones in this game are worthy challenges if you are up to it. Many people complain about the spawns, but unless you play with the permanent tunnels option, there's nothing stopping you from redesigning and moving your trains around whenever you feel a redesign is in order. I often have several trains crisscrossing between stations to keep the variety of stations favorable.Islands though can be a pain. Tunnels and bridges are given sparingly, and often at a cost of a new line, or train car which would increase your capacity. I often find it better to have longer cars move people around on an island of just circles, with a short rail with two long cars taking all the squares and triangles to the nearest one on the other shore. Islands with multiple rare symbols are often best split up if you can manage it as well.In short, it's a game that can keep your mind active while you wind down for the evening. The graphics and music are minimal, but entrancing, and the challenges are well chosen. I hope they add more content at some point.I also bought this for my Android for $4.99 I liked it so much so I can play it on the go. Touch controls are a bit touchy, but that's for another review.

Posted: July 20, 2015
												tldr: Wonderful puzzler. Nothing "Mini" about the replayability, in case that word has put you off. :)As with so many great puzzlers, this game is simple to play but with a lot of depth. A few tools are given to you at the start of a map (tracks, trains, tunnels), a few more that are offered as choices as time passes. And as time passes, you get more passengers to ferry around, and more stations you need to connect to the network.With your basic building blocks you need to keep passengers moving from station to station. Some of these are unique stations that appear only once on the map, and some are repeated. Handily enough, passengers are happy to go to any one of the stations of the same shape - if only everyone using an city underground was as care-free with their destination!Anyway, the thing I recommend most of all is that you stop reading reviews, go to the publishers' website and try it out online. Then come back here and buy it.At the time of writing this game is in alpha, but it's very polished, and and bugs are fixed very quickly indeed. I _am_ hoping they'll get the audio in before the heat-death of the universe, as the video released showing a sneak peak of that looked good, too!Enjoy!UPDATE: It's been out of Alpha for a long time, and is still a great game (better, even, with a great soundtrack / sfx, and all sort of quality-of-life fixes)!

Early Access Review
								This is a great game. The one thing I would change is that each piece transported should pay a fare, then at the end of the week, the player should have the option to use the fare to buy a new line, a new carriage, or build a tunnel/bridge. The way it is now, it is completely random, and nothing is more frustrating than having a beautiful, efficient map, then having a station show up on an island when you don't have a tunnel, then not having a choice to build a new tunnel at the end of the week. Maybe this is the effect that the developers are going for since this is a puzzle game, but it can be pretty annoying.Also, why is Hong Kong so ♥♥♥♥ing hard????

												The Game crashes frequently. I have checked, this is the game itself, it even did so after a restart. I have played the Unity Web Version and that actually worked. I like the game concept but the developer needs to think about his decisions on this one. $10 for a game that is at best broken.

Posted: December 19, 2015
												Mini Metro is a revelation; it's been a very long time since I last played a game so original and addictive. Picking up the basics of the game takes moments, but the more you play it, the more you see the inherent depth in the game. The various playable cities at first seem very similar, but after a while you realise that each requires very different strategies. The minimalist art design is excellent. The use of smooth crisp, sharply coloured diagrams really makes you feel like you are creating a tube map. It's amazing how immersive such a graphically simple game can be.I have a few minor gripes; occasionally trains get stuck in the stations for no apparent reason. The random spawning of stations, whilst giving great replayability, can also sometimes make games unplayable. But these are minor issues and I hope they will be fixed soon,The game is a natural fit for tablets and I'll be interested to see a release there, and hoping this will see it get more attention. In my view a real classic.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												This puzzle game is surprisingly very soothing.  The music is procedurally generated and is mostly made up of subway beeps and tweeting birds.  When you hit the Game Over screen, the music just fades away as the sound of waves plays over the effect.  Aesthetically, it’s also very soothing, even though Colorblind Mode tends to put the most obnoxious yellow against a white background that makes it barely visible.  Gameplay is very simple and kind of therapeutic.  This is one of the few puzzle games where I didn’t find myself swearing at the game when they would change something up to make it more challenging.I definately recommend this game, especially if you want to play a low-stress time-killer puzzle game.

Posted: December 19, 2015
												Love this game, can be very intense (yes I know) and very zen at other times. Endless mode is really nice, much more relaxing. The game is a very good timekiller, and if you own a 2-in-1 laptop (like me), it is fully touchscreen compatible, making it an absolutely fantastic game. Love the game, love the design, love everything about it.

Posted: August 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game took forever to get sound effects (like over a year) but it now has sound effects, which make the game playable. I'd say that the game is now at a level where I can recommend it, if you like this sort of game. I'm still very wary of this developer, and won't be supporting any future early access games they release since they're extremely slow, but this particular game is now at a level where it is playable, so whilst I don't endore the developer, I do think this game is worth it.Its very "pick up and play", whilst also being enjoyable for longer periods. Lots of clicking, so if you struggle with carpal tunnel syndrome, this may not be the game for you. It also uses colours for distinguishing gameplay elements, which may be difficult for some colour blind players, but the main colours do seem to have been chosen well; red, blue, green, pink, orange etc, so many colour blind players should still be okay with this game; get someone to check first to see if it is okay for you.I would suggest having some kind of podcast playing so that you can zone out if you're going to play for a couple of hours.*This review was edited after sound effects were added. It used to not recommend the game due to the lack of sound and the length of time that it was taking for an early access game. Whilst I still have major negative feelings towards the developer, this product is at a level where I can give a fair review.

Posted: December 11, 2015
												Very relaxing little game. It's not something you'll play for long sessions (unless you're really into simulators), but it's lovely to just sit down and play a few rounds.Oh, and the devs have a map editor (hopefully with steam workshop support) on their list, so when that comes out, you can play on any city you want!

Posted: December 11, 2015
												Probably the best casual puzzler I have ever touched.Beautiful in it's gameplay and design. Each level you try to keep your system running in is a work of art in itself.If you have any interest in puzzles, subways / trains, casual gaming, art, or wasting endless hours in bliss, get this now.*** UPDATE ***After playing this for several hours now, I do see that it has some balance and gameplay mechanic issues that hurt it's replayability long term.I feel like this game could have a lot more depth than it does with a few simple changes.Currently the game relys heavily on random scaled spawning to increase difficulty. However because of this, it makes it almost impossible to reach a higher level once you hit the apex on the particular map you are playing.This ensures a short game, but to be honest, hurts the fun a bit as it makes your infrastructure decisions not really matter. The late game is mostly about shuffling around trains and lines to prevent the end temporarily in one particular area. Which then crops up in a different area, etc.I was hoping for deeper gameplay such as having predefined areas of higher population and being able to tweak your lines to have express trains, and multiple trains utilizing a tunnel.The complex railway management just isn't there.But what this game is is a fun, yet casual puzzler, with short rounds that you expect to end after you hit 1,000 people utilizing the same strategy over and over.This is a bit of a disappointment for me but I hold out hope for the developers to keep working on it.I see a LOT of potential here.

Early Access Review
								I love this game, the minimalist style is beautiful. It is well designed and unique, in my experience. However, I have a few criticisms, that i think could help improve the depth and breadth of gameplay greatly. 1. Customers using the transport system should be able to pay for its , for a price set by the player.This could generate income, too buy upgrades for the system. 2. Statistics on how each line is performing, too anticipate traffic, capacity and demand.3. Allowing for the building of more than seven lines at a time, this is an arbitrary limit with little practical use in the game.4. Enabling lines to have multiple branches that diverge and converge with eachother.5.  What about multiplayer?

Posted: January 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Whether or not you're a strategist or a master micro-manager, or just want to try this game in general, this is a really good game, I've had some fun with this game. Commuter is for people who like a good challenge, and Scenic is just for people who wants to experiment and or just play without worrying about too many passengers on platforms.So far I have been able to give a single train 8 coaches, 9 if you include the loco itself. Each coach and locomotive holds 6 passengers. The stations are commonly Circle, Triangle and Square. The uniques being Gem, Diamond, Plus, Pizza shaped thing, star and a few more.This game is a must for anyone who wants a cheap game that's fun, easy to play and has an easy User Interface.9/10 (the other 1 was deducted due to not many choices of cities, hopefully this will change as they update it.)

Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								The simplicity of this game reminds me of go. The concepts are simple and easy to grasp but the game quickly becomes increasing difficult, challenging the player to plan ahead or get crushed by the number of people trying to use the station. Just bought it and couldn't put it down for 4 hours. While this is in beta, it is perhaps one of the most complete and fun betas I've playing in a long time, and is really only missing audio (which is coming soon).  Can't say enough about the UI as well. Clean and crisp and easy to navigate. Definitely looks like a london underground system map. At present build (beta 15) this game is an 8/10. Once complete I can't image it being anything less than a 10/10. Buy it! Really inexpensive for the fun. (P.S. to the dev's, this game would be awesome on an Ipad.)

Posted: January 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Both cohesive and pleasing to the eye, this train game is not just another train game.  While this has been said of almost every train game, Minimetro, offers simple game mechanics with increasing difficulty that provide entertainment and a challenge for anyone.  Micromanage, in realtime, a subway system in one of the world's greatest metropoli. Prevent your stations from overcrowding in an effort to get all of your passengers to their destination.  Offering three gamemodes of varying difficulty, The game can be easily picked up, but will continue to provide a challenge for months to come to even the greatest strategist.   Certainly worth its value this early access game only lacks a soundtrack. Glitchfree and carefree this game excels!

Posted: December 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Alright. So this game is straightfowarldy AWESOME.If you expect a hardcore, uber-realistic metro/railway sim - that's not your game, definetly. If you're in for some relaxation... well... maaybe.Generally, what are you going to do while playing this game is trying to fix everything, while it all goes to HELL. Seriously) Mini Metro always starts on a fairly slow pace, but then picks up... And suddenly you're knee deep in ♥♥♥♥♥♥ overcrowded stations, juggling trains from lane to lane and desperatly struggling to save the day, while new stations keep popping at the places you least want them to spawn at. Sounds horrible - but it delivers almost heaven-like feeling of peace and enjoyment. Don't believe me? Try out the free demo on devs' site, it does pretty much develop it.The design is genuine. A masterpiece, a pure delight for eyes. Hope developers would come up with some decent music to match it (some ambient, maybe?), otherwise half the game experience would be ruined ;(  Criteria  Score   Graphics 11/10   Gameplay 10/10   Replayability 8/10   OVERALL 10/10

Posted: December 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is a game about management, Simple and intuitive UI/UX keeps you on the edge of your seat, not because of action or thrill; but rather micro-management and the thought of "How can I make this metro better?” The actual gameplay is satisfying and also link to the UI/UX simplicity. Something about those little rectangles carrying triangles, squares, wedges, etc. is extremely addicting.The added game modes complement the experience my introducing casual modes, different aesthetics and varying maps that subtly change the experience. Highly recommended for those who love a simple puzzle game. Although it would be a shame not to see a mobile port of this game.

It's very easy to grasp in a few minutes, whilst you can waste hours at a time on it trying to get to the top of the leaderboard.Surely, it may be a bit boring for some, but for those like me who don't play RPGs and stuff like that, it's a brilliant game.

Posted: February 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mini metro is a wonderful little time waster. if you've got a few minutes to kill and you want something simple to tide you over every now and then you could do far worse. There's something addictive about trying to build the perfect metro that can cope with whatever the game throws at you but you can only do that for so long before one backwater station gets overcrowded to the point of what I assume is acidental death when one of the little shapes falls onto the tracks because the station is packed full of other shapes waiting for their connection. It's simple fun really - there's not much more to it than that. I will say that once you figure out the formula to getting a decent high score the game starts to lose a lot of it's replay value but that said - I still pick it up now and then to kill time before I have to go to work in the morning. as a side note, It's lovely to see colourblind options for this game. along with that the UI is clean and eye pleasing.

Posted: May 16, 2016
												I bought this while in early access as part of the Humble Indie Bundle.I really like some odd games, I think my other reivews note that pretty well. I played a lot of city planners when I was younger, but I always got caught up in how complex they would be (damn you, SimCity 2000!). Mini Metro is a fantastic, stripped-down city planner: all you have to worry about is getting people on to trains, and off of trains. It's incredibly engaging and relaxing, and after the most recent update, includes a great procedural soundtrack from Disaterpeace (Hyper Light Drifter, FEZ) that I wish I could just leave running while I'm working. It's endlessly replayable, and just... so good. Excellent.

								Pros:-Smart-Addictive-Simple & Functional UI-Detected my main language, changed the game language accordingly, ability to change to another one.-Updated regularly-Potential to be a big hit-Great support & website-In game leaderboardCons:-No sound ( yet, it will be added soon )-You might get panic attacks when stations start to get fullMy advice: Get it

Posted: October 13, 2014
Early Access Review
Just when you thought you had it under control... Another bloody circle station appears...Mini Metro is where you're in charge or a city's transportation. People need to get going. You're the one in charge. You can't screw up. Mini Metro is where things can escalate within a matter of minutes. You'll have about 3 lines connecting to 5 or so stations and then you'll have some strange trickery of loops and squiggles of so-called train lines.There are the ocassional bugs that appear rarely, but notable. When you have a train with more than 8 carriages *i know...*, it can teleport when you've redrawn a line that completely exposes it's temporary line. So basically, when you redraw the track so much so that your train is off the newly drawn track, the train will teleport to the nearest station that the newly drawn line is connected to.Now, of course, this is in Early Access. So, I'm telling you right now, get the game. For $7, it's worth every cent. 10/10, would buy again.

Posted: October 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Mini Metro is a remarkably excellent game. Its simplicity is deceptive - whilst it is incredibly addictive and looks beautifully, it is surprisingly difficult and can get rather manic as your network grows. I'm not usually a fan of zen-type games but Mini Metro is a very pleasant surprise. Completely addictive and brilliant replay value too since every game will undoubtedly be different. An absolute steal for the current price!
